FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/giant-slow-cooker-meatballs/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 lb. ground beef (85/15) \n1/2 lb. Italian sausage (mild, sweet, or hot)\n1 large egg, slightly beaten\n1/2 cup plain breadcrumbs \n1/4 cup grated Parmesan \n1/4 tsp onion powder\n1/4 tsp garlic powder\n1/4 tsp salt \n1 26 oz. jar marinara sauce \n12 oz. spaghetti \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Add the ground beef, Italian sausage, beaten egg, breadcrumbs, Parmesan, onion powder, garlic powder, and salt to a bowl. Use your hands to combine the ingredients until they are evenly mixed. \n2. Divide the mixture into four equal portions, then shape each into a ball.\n3. Place the meatballs in the slow cooker and pour the marinara over top, making sure to coat the top of each meatball. The sauce will only come up about half way to the top of the meatballs, but that's okay. The slow cooker will fill with steam, which will help cook the meatballs even though they are not completely submerged.\n4. Place the lid on the slow cooker and then cook on high for 3 hours, or low for 6-7 hours. Use an instant read thermometer to make sure the meatballs have reached at least 160\u00baF on the inside (mine had exceeded this temperature after 3 hours on high). \n5. Near the end of the cook time, cook the spaghetti according to the package directions, and then drain in a colander.\n6. Remove the cooked meatballs from the slow cooker, then add the cooked and drained spaghetti, and toss it to coat in the sauce. Divide the sauced spaghetti between four plates, add one giant meatball to each, then enjoy.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2018-12-30T17:01:24+00:00", "duration": "PT1M7S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/-GTAQl2MAm4/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/-GTAQl2MAm4?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-GTAQl2MAm4", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT180M", "totalTime": "PT190M", "recipeIngredient": ["1/2 lb. ground beef (85/15) ($2.65)", "1/2 lb. Thanks for such a great recipe!\u00a0", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Lauren K"}, "datePublished": "2018-12-16"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "We are swooning! So glad I doubled the recipe so I have extras to freeze. A really satisfying meal. I'm a snob about powdered onion and garlic, but I actually bought onion powder (good-quality) just to try in this recipe. It was wonderful! I did make a couple changes:\r\n\r\nFor those interested in reducing the fat in this recipe, I made this a day ahead (minus the spaghetti), separated the sauce from the meatballs, after a night in the fridge I just skimmed the fat off the top.\r\n\r\nAnd if you're using super-lean meat, instead of dry breadcrumbs, for each batch use a slice of bread (crust off) soaked in milk, yes skim is fine, just enough for the whole slice to be drenched; give this step a few minutes because the bread will absorb more and more liquid and you want it nice and gooey. Then use only an egg white or yolk, not the whole thing. \r\n\r\nI wish I could remember where I picked up that technique, because it's great for when you don't have bread crumbs around and it's also a great binder that keeps meatballs or meatloaf tender even if it's 95% lean meat. That's why you want plenty of milk, though no extra (that is, don't add any milk that pools on the dish at the end).\r\n\r\nI don't use jarred marinara but poured in a large can of crushed tomatoes and added my preferred Italian herbs, heavy on the fennel.\r\n\r\nThanks so much for this one! It's cold and achy here and we were in the mood for something satisfying. Used whole-grain pasta. Also used hot sausage which gave these just the right amount of kick. The heat is cut nicely by the other ingredients. Making great food is my passion, my purpose, and my favorite thing to share with others.", "sameAs": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/about/", "https://www.facebook.com/budgetbytes1", "https://x.com/Budget_Bytes"], "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/author/beth/"}, {"@type": "Recipe", "name": "Cajun Sausage and Rice Skillet", "author": {"@id": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/#/schema/person/de533a4dad507aefcf8ea04e131701f9"}, "description": "This easy Cajun Sausage and Rice Skillet is the perfect easy and filling weeknight dinner, packed with plenty of smoky-spicy flavor!Step-by-step photos can be seen below the recipe card.", "datePublished": "2020-09-17T12:27:13+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Cajun-Sausage-and-Rice-Skillet-front.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Cajun-Sausage-and-Rice-Skillet-front-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Cajun-Sausage-and-Rice-Skillet-front-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Cajun-Sausage-and-Rice-Skillet-front-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Cajun Sausage and Rice Skillet", "description": "You can call this recipe \"Jambalaya light\" because it's the same flavors and same technique in a faster, more simplified format, perfect for busy weeknights! FULL RECIPE BELOW. \ud83d\udc47\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/cajun-sausage-and-rice-skillet/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n14 oz. Andouille sausage* ($3.99)\n1 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.04)\n1 bell pepper ($0.89)\n1 tsp smoked paprika ($0.10)\n1/2 tsp dried oregano ($0.05)\n1/2 tsp dried thyme ($0.05)\n1/4 tsp garlic powder ($0.02)\n1/4 tsp onion powder ($0.02)\n1/8 tsp cayenne pepper ($0.02)\n1/8 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.01)\n1 15oz. can fire roasted diced tomatoes ($1.00)\n1 cup long grain white rice ($0.62)\n1.5 cups chicken broth ($0.20)\n2 green onions, sliced ($0.20)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Slice the sausage into \u00bc-\u00bd inch thick slices. Add the sausage and cooking oil to a deep skillet or Dutch oven and saut\u00e9 over medium heat until the sausage is well browned. Don't worry if the sausage begins to brown on the bottom of the skillet. That's extra flavor that will cook into the rice later.\n2. While the sausage is cooking, dice the bell pepper. Once the sausage is browned, add the bell pepper to the skillet and continue to saut\u00e9 for about one more minute.\n3. Add the spices (smoked paprika, oregano, thyme, garlic powder, onion powder, cayenne, and black pepper) to the skillet with the sausage and bell pepper and continue to saut\u00e9 for one minute more to toast the spices.\n4. Add the fire roasted diced tomatoes (with juices), rice, and chicken broth to the skillet. Stir to combine and dissolve any browned bits off the bottom of the skillet.\n5. Place a lid on the skillet, turn the heat up to medium-high, and allow the broth to come to a full boil. Once it reaches a boil, turn the heat down to low and let the skillet simmer for 20 minutes. After 20 minutes, remove the skillet from the heat and let it rest, with the lid on, for an additional 5 minutes.\n6. After the skillet has rested, remove the lid, and fold the sausage and rice to redistribute the rice and sausage throughout. Top with sliced green onions and serve!\n\nNOTES\n*If you can not find Andouille in your area, use any smoked pork sausage.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/ \n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Intro\n0:07 Brown the sausage in the skillet\n0:15 Add bell pepper\n0:19 Add spices\n0:28 Add tomatoes, rice, and broth\n0:37 Simmer\n0:42 Stir and add green onion\n0:52 Serve and enjoy!", "uploadDate": "2020-10-18T15:00:11+00:00", "duration": "PT1M5S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/iLKddjZ057c/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/iLKddjZ057c?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iLKddjZ057c", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4", "4 1.5 cups each"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT30M", "totalTime": "PT45M", "recipeIngredient": ["14 oz. Bake two or ten frozen slices at a time, ready in minutes!&nbsp;", "datePublished": "2018-08-28T19:36:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Freezer-Garlic-Bread-close.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Freezer-Garlic-Bread-close-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Freezer-Garlic-Bread-close-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Freezer-Garlic-Bread-close-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Freezer Garlic Bread", "description": "Make your own homemade freezer garlic bread slices, ready to bake on demand. Bake two or ten frozen slices at a time, ready in minutes! FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/homemade-freezer-garlic-bread/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n8 Tbsp salted butter, room temperature\n2 Tbsp olive oil \n4 cloves garlic, minced \n1/4 tsp garlic powder \n1/4 tsp salt \n1 Tbsp dried parsley \n1 loaf French bread \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Add the butter, olive oil, minced garlic, garlic powder, salt, and parsley to a bowl. Mix the ingredients together until they form a fairly smooth mixture.\n2. Slice the French bread into 1-inch thick slices (12-16 slices, depending on the size of the loaf). Add 1/2 to 1 Tbsp of the garlic spread to each slice of bread and spread it from edge to edge. Arrange the slices on a baking sheet and then place them in the freezer for about 30 minutes to allow the butter to firm up. Once firm, transfer the garlic bread to a gallon-sized freezer bag for longer storage. Store in the freezer up to three months.\n3. To cook the frozen slices of garlic bread, preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Once the oven is heated, take as many slices out of the freezer as you'd like, and place them on a baking sheet. Bake for 10-15 minutes, or until the edges are golden brown.* If you prefer a softer garlic bread without crispy edges, wrap the slices in foil before baking.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-05-26T19:23:34+00:00", "duration": "PT1M2S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/pwxI9kAN_28/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/pwxI9kAN_28?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pwxI9kAN_28", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["12", "12 to 16 slices"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeIngredient": ["8 Tbsp salted butter, room temperature ($1.04)", "2 Tbsp olive oil  ($0.32)", "4 cloves garlic, minced ($0.32)", "1/4 tsp garlic powder ($0.02)", "1/4 tsp salt  ($0.02)", "1 Tbsp dried parsley  ( $0.30)", "1 loaf French bread  ($1.00)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the butter, olive oil, minced garlic, garlic powder, salt, and parsley to a bowl. Just like The Olive Garden&#039;s, but made from scratch!", "datePublished": "2025-04-12T08:30:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/zuppa-toscana-bowl.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/zuppa-toscana-bowl-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/zuppa-toscana-bowl-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/zuppa-toscana-bowl-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Zuppa Toscana", "description": "This homemade version Olive Garden's Zuppa Toscana is slightly lighter, but every bit as creamy, filling, and flavorful as the original! FULL RECIPE BELOW\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/zuppa-toscana/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 lb. Italian Sausage, hot or mild\n1 yellow onion\n2 cloves garlic\n1 15 oz. can Great Northern beans\n1/2 tsp smoked paprika\n3 cups chicken broth\n1 cup water\n2 cups half and half\n1 lb. red potatoes\n1/2 lb. kale, chopped\npinch red pepper flakes, optional\nfreshly cracked black pepper, optional\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n\n1. Add the sausage to a large soup pot and saut\u00e9 over medium heat, breaking it up into small pieces as it cooks. The sausage should contain enough fat to keep it from sticking, if not add a touch of olive oil. It's okay if a small amount browns on the bottom of the pot.\n\n2. While the sausage is cooking, dice the onion and mince the garlic. Add the onion and garlic to the pot and saut\u00e9 until the onions are softened. The moisture from the onions should help dissolve any browned bits of sausage off the bottom of the pot.\n\n3. Drain and rinse the can of beans. Add the beans, smoked paprika, chicken broth, one cup water, and half and half to the pot. Place a lid on the pot and let it come up to a simmer over medium heat.\n\n4. While the pot is heating, cut each potato into quarters lengthwise, then slice across into thin, 1/8-inch thick slices. Add the potatoes to the pot along with the pre-chopped kale. The kale will fill the pot when it's first added, but the heat from the liquid will wilt it within a few minutes. Stir it occasionally to help the wilting process.\n\n5. Let the pot simmer over medium heat for about 15 minutes, or until the potatoes are tender. Season with red pepper flakes and freshly cracked black pepper if desired.\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-12-01T15:30:19+00:00", "duration": "PT1M1S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/jT1qmnUwkxc/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/jT1qmnUwkxc?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jT1qmnUwkxc", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["8", "8 (1.5 cups each)"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT30M", "totalTime": "PT45M", "recipeIngredient": ["1/2 lb. Bring everything to a gentle simmer (don&#39;t let it boil!).", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/zuppa-toscana/#wprm-recipe-31560-step-0-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Season with red pepper flakes and freshly cracked black pepper if desired.", "name": "Season with red pepper flakes and freshly cracked black pepper if desired.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/zuppa-toscana/#wprm-recipe-31560-step-0-6"}], "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "ratingValue": "4.83", "ratingCount": "160", "reviewCount": "12"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "I made this with creamy unsweetened oat milk instead of the half and half, turned out great!  Will make again!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Julie Taylor"}, "datePublished": "2025-10-26"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Super easy to make and SOOOO tasty! Must have for fall!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Lindsey"}, "datePublished": "2025-10-14"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "This is THE BEST soup I have EVER made or eaten. In the spirit of keeping things low budget, I subbed and added some things based on what I already had at home. I used 3 hot Italian sausages with the casings removed, and added ~15 ish plain frozen meatballs that I tossed in with the browning meat and that I broke up once they were thawed. I also used 1 cup of beef broth that I had leftover from another recipe and 3 cups of water. I used heavy whipping cream and added one roughly diced zucchini as well because I needed to use them up. Even with all of the alterations, this was HANDS DOWN the BEST SOUP I've EVER eaten. I've never posted a comment on a recipe before, but I had to with this one. As soon as I had the first bite, I immediately was like \"I gotta send this recipe to everyone\". I was hesitant to try it because I thought it might be bland or the beans might overpower the taste or texture, but it was SO perfectly flavourful! And the texture is almost like eating chili! FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nGet recipe FAQs and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/funfetti-mug-cake/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup all-purpose flour ($0.03)\n1 Tbsp sugar ($0.02)\n1/4 tsp baking powder ($0.02)\n1 tsp rainbow sprinkles ($0.10)\n3 Tbsp milk ($0.08)\n1 Tbsp butter (melted) ($0.09)\n1/4 tsp vanilla extract ($0.07)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Add the flour, sugar, baking powder, and sprinkles to a microwave safe mug (8oz. or larger). Stir until everything is well combined.\n2. Add the milk, melted butter, and vanilla extract to the mug. Stir until a soft batter forms, making sure to scrape all the flour out of the corners of the mug.\n3. Microwave the mug cake for about 60 seconds, or until it has puffed to about 2-3 times the volume. Cook time will vary with the wattage of your microwave (I used a 1000 watt microwave and 60-70 seconds was perfect).\n4. Allow the mug cake to cool for a few minutes and then top with your preferred frosting option, or enjoy unfrosted.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:09 Combine dry ingredients\n0:16 Add wet ingredients\n0:20 Stir to combine\n0:24 Microwave\n0:27 Top with frosting or whipped cream\n0:31 Enjoy!", "uploadDate": "2021-07-25T15:42:53+00:00", "duration": "PT38S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/rdu10-X8eVw/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/rdu10-X8eVw?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rdu10-X8eVw", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["1"], "prepTime": "PT4M", "cookTime": "PT1M", "totalTime": "PT5M", "recipeIngredient": ["1/4 cup all-purpose flour ($0.03)", "1 Tbsp sugar ($0.02)", "1/4 tsp baking powder ($0.02)", "1 tsp rainbow sprinkles ($0.10)", "3 Tbsp milk ($0.08)", "1 Tbsp butter (melted) ($0.09)", "1/4 tsp vanilla extract ($0.07)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the flour, sugar, baking powder, and sprinkles to a microwave safe mug (8oz. or larger). Perfect for meal prep!Step-by-step photos can be seen below the recipe card.", "datePublished": "2018-01-23T18:22:12+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/Sheet-Pan-BBQ-Meatloaf-Dinner-plate.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/Sheet-Pan-BBQ-Meatloaf-Dinner-plate-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/Sheet-Pan-BBQ-Meatloaf-Dinner-plate-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/Sheet-Pan-BBQ-Meatloaf-Dinner-plate-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Sheet Pan BBQ Meatloaf Dinner", "description": "This incredibly easy and tasty Sheet Pan BBQ Meatloaf Dinner cooks together on one sheet pan! Dinner doesn't get easier than this. FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/2018/01/sheet-pan-bbq-meatloaf-dinner/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\nVEGETABLES\n1 sweet potato (about 1 lb.) \n12 oz. frozen broccoli florets \n2 Tbsp olive oil \n1/2 tsp seasoning salt* \nsalt and pepper to taste \nBBQ MEATLOAF\n1/2 lb. ground beef\n1 large egg \n2 Tbsp bread crumbs\n3 Tbsp BBQ sauce, divided \n1/4 tsp smoked paprika \n1/8 tsp garlic powder\n1/4 tsp salt \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. Peel the sweet potato and cut it into 1/2 to 3/4\" cubes. Place the sweet potatoes and frozen broccoli florets (no need to thaw) on a large baking sheet.\n2. Drizzle the olive oil over the sweet potatoes and broccoli florets. Sprinkle the seasoning salt over the sweet potatoes and then season the broccoli florets with a pinch of salt and pepper. Use your hands to toss the vegetables until they are coated in oil and spices, keeping the sweet potatoes on one side of the baking sheet and the broccoli on the other.\n3. Transfer the baking sheet to the preheated oven and roast the vegetables for 15 minutes.\n4. While the vegetables are roasting, prepare the meatloaves. In a medium bowl combine the ground beef, egg, bread crumbs, 1 Tbsp of the BBQ sauce, the smoked paprika, garlic powder, and salt. Work the ingredients together with your hands or a fork until they are well combined. Divide the meatloaf mixture in two and shape each half into a flattened oval.\n5. After the vegetables have roasted for 15 minutes, remove the baking sheet and stir each of the vegetables. Push each off to the side a bit to make room for the meatloaves. Place the shaped meatloaves in the center and then spread 1 Tbsp of BBQ sauce over each loaf.\n6. Return the baking sheet to the oven and roast for an additional 20 minutes, or until the internal temperature of the meatloaves has reached 160\u00baF. Remove the baking sheet from the oven, plate up the meatloaves and vegetables, and serve immediately.\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2018-02-12T16:01:34+00:00", "duration": "PT1M28S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/TU06-LUHJ-A/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/TU06-LUHJ-A?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TU06-LUHJ-A", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["2"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT35M", "totalTime": "PT45M", "recipeIngredient": ["1  sweet potato (about 1 lb., $1.86)", "12 oz. frozen broccoli ($1.16*)", "2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.44)", "\u00bd tsp seasoning salt ($0.05**)", "salt (to taste, $0.02)", "black pepper (to taste, $0.03)", "\u00bd lb. ground beef (80/20, $2.49)", "1 large egg ($0.37)", "2 Tbsp bread crumbs (plain, $0.12)", "3 Tbsp BBQ sauce (divided, $0.26)", "\u00bc tsp smoked paprika ($0.03)", "\u215b tsp  garlic powder ($0.02)", "\u00bc tsp  salt ($0.02)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. FULL RECIPE BELOW. \n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/tortilla-baked-eggs/\n\nIngredients\n    1/2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.18)\n    1 8\" flour tortilla ($0.14)\n    1 cup fresh spinach ($0.16)\n    4 large eggs ($0.23)\n    1/8 tsp salt ($0.01)\n    1/8 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.01)\n    1/2 cup grape tomatoes ($0.37)\n    1/4 cup shredded cheddar ($0.21)\n    1/8 tsp crushed red pepper (optional) ($0.01)\n\nInstructions\n1. Preheat the oven to 350\u00baF. Brush the inside of a round, 7-inch diameter oven safe dish* with olive oil. Press the tortilla down into the dish so that the edges of the tortilla are folded up the sides of the dish (see step by step photos below).\n2. Roughly chop the spinach then add it to the bottom of the tortilla. Crack the four eggs into the tortilla on top of the spinach. Add a pinch of salt and pepper on top of the eggs.\n3. Slice the grap tomatoes in half, then sprinkle them over the eggs. Finally, top with shredded cheese.\n4. Bake the egg filled tortilla in the oven for 20-25 minutes, or until the whites are set and the yolks are still jammy. You can shake the dish to see if the whites still jiggle or if they are set. Baking time may vary depending on the size of your tortilla and number of eggs used.\n 5. Remove the tortilla baked eggs from the oven and slide them out of the dish. Slice into four pieces, then serve!\nNotes\n*You can use any size oven-safe round dish, but make sure you use a tortilla of a slightly larger size than the dish. For instance, you can use an 8-inch pie tin, but you\u2019ll want to use a tortilla that is approximately 9-inches in diameter. Cooking time may vary depending on the size of your dish and tortilla. See step 4 above for a tip on how to tell it\u2019s finished baking.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:11 Coat Baking Dish in Oil\n0:13 Press Tortilla into Dish\n0:16 Add Spinach\n0:18 Add Eggs\n0:21 Add Salt & Pepper\n0:23 Add Tomatoes\n0:26 Add Cheese\n0:30 Bake\n0:38 Slice & Serve", "uploadDate": "2021-01-24T15:30:09+00:00", "duration": "PT54S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/zLC0uNEgiqA/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/zLC0uNEgiqA?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLC0uNEgiqA", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["2"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeIngredient": ["1/2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.08)", "1 8&quot; flour tortilla ($0.14)", "1 cup fresh spinach ($0.16)", "4 large eggs ($0.92)", "1/8 tsp salt ($0.01)", "1/8 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.01)", "1/2 cup grape tomatoes ($0.37)", "1/4 cup shredded cheddar ($0.21)", "1/8 tsp crushed red pepper (optional) ($0.01)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00baF. If I don't have any fresh herbs I throw on some Mrs Dash Garlic &amp; Herb, salt, and paprika. \u00a0If I'm pressed for time, I will microwave for about ~5 minutes until they're soft, then broil on high until they're brown.\u00a0", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Bethany"}, "datePublished": "2018-09-06"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "This is my  go-to recipe for a quick and tasty potato side dish. I've tried it with fresh herbs and have found that they burn with the high heat, leaving a rather bitter flavor. Instead, I use 1/2 teaspooon each of dried rosemary, Kosher salt and dried thyme, along with 1/4 teaspoon dried dill. I also substitute the minced garlic with garlic-infused olive oil, to enhance the herb's true flavor. To make the infused oil, I add  2 large cloves of crushed garlic and 2 tablespoons of olive oil to a small skillet. On medium-low heat,  simmer the cloves, uncovered for about 5 minutes. Discard the cloves, let oil cool and use the desired amount for tossing potatoes with the herbs. I  use some of the remaining oil for brushing a foil-lined  pan for roasting and toss the hot potatoes with paprika and fresh parsley, before adding to a serving dish. On those hot summer days, I've also used the exact recipe on a preheated  outdoor grill. Roasting is over medium-high heat, stirring the potatoes occasionally to avoid burning. Depending on potato size, I check for doneness at about 25 minutes.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Robert Hicks"}, "datePublished": "2018-09-06"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Another hint--I always spray my old sheet pans with some sort of cooking spray so things don't stick. It cuts down on the amount of oil you need for marinating, although 1 T for 1.5 lbs of potatoes is already appropriately stingy", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Janet"}, "datePublished": "2018-09-06"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Growing up on a farm, using new potatoes was always a highlight of the harvest season. My dad tried to wait until all of the potatoes we would use over the winter were sizeable, but there were always tiny ones that my mom snagged as \"creamers,\" and that's how she used them--boiled, served in white sauce (bechamel) and passed under the broiler to slightly brown the tops. My preference for the past 5-10 years has been to roast them, either alone, or as part of a veggie combo including whole garlic and onions plus green, orange and/or red things--also friends of rosemary.\r\n\r\nWhile this recipe, as Beth says, will work with any potato, the tiny ones have a tighter texture and a deliciousness not found in mature potatoes. I think rosemary has a particular affinity with potatoes and it's one of the easiest herbs to grow either in a pot or a protected part of a yard--remember to water it, and it may last indefinitely. I don't know how far north it is hardy, but I have a 15 yr old bush here in central NC and left another one of similar age behind in Austin, TX.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Janet"}, Although prices are all over the place, you can buy a good Lodge pan for just over $20 at Amazon--or possibly your local hardware store--and can often find them for less at garage sales and places like Goodwill. Avoid those that are either enameled or nonstick as they are not intended to heat beyond medium. I picked up my 10\" square Lodge at a garage sale some years ago for $2.00, source of most of my cast iron pans. Mine was rusted, but bringing cast iron back to life isn't difficult and plenty of YouTube videos show how to do it. Anyone can make this rich and creamy lemon butter sauce! FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nGet recipe FAQs and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/easy-hollandaise-sauce/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 large egg, separated ($0.23)\n1 Tbsp water ($0.00)\n1/2 Tbsp lemon juice ($0.02)\n4 Tbsp butter* ($0.44)\n1/8 tsp salt ($0.01)\n1/8 tsp cayenne pepper ($0.02)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Separate the egg and place the egg yolk in a small saucepot. The whites can be saved for a different recipe.\n2. Add the water and lemon juice to the pot with the yolk and whisk until smooth (no heat yet).\n3. Cut the butter into small pieces (about \u00bc Tbsp size) , then add them to the saucepot with the egg yolk, lemon, and water.\n4. Place the pot over medium-low heat. Continuously whisk as the mixture heats. First the butter will melt, then the mixture will begin to get a bit frothy. Finally, as the egg yolk begins to cook, the sauce will thicken. Make sure you're whisking the entire time to achieve a light, smooth sauce. Once it thickens to the consistency of gravy, remove the pot from the heat.\n5. Season the sauce with salt and cayenne, then drizzle the sauce over your favorite food!\nNOTES\n*I use salted butter, but if you have unsalted butter simply add a pinch more salt to your sauce.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:09 Combine egg yolk, water, and lemon juice\n0:16 Add butter\n0:18 Turn on heat and whisk until thickened\n0:33 Remove from heat and season\n0:46 Serve and enjoy!", "uploadDate": "2021-07-18T14:00:27+00:00", "duration": "PT1M1S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/9qXd_TBy2Y8/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/9qXd_TBy2Y8?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9qXd_TBy2Y8", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["2", "2 3 Tbsp each"], "prepTime": "PT2M", "cookTime": "PT5M", "totalTime": "PT7M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 large egg, separated ($0.23)", "1 Tbsp water ($0.00)", "1/2 Tbsp lemon juice ($0.02)", "4 Tbsp butter* ($0.44)", "1/8 tsp salt ($0.01)", "1/8 tsp cayenne pepper ($0.02)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Separate the egg and place the egg yolk in a small saucepot. Stir to dissolve and let sit for five minutes or until the surface is covered with foam.", "name": "In a small bowl combine the honey, yeast and 1.25 cups warm water. Stir to dissolve and let sit for five minutes or until the surface is covered with foam.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/cinnamon-raisin-bagels/#wprm-recipe-33514-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl combine 2 cups of the flour and the salt. Stir to combine. Add the frothy yeast water and stir well until everything is evenly mixed. Continue adding flour 1/2 cup at a time until it is too hard to stir by hand (about one cup later). Turn the dough out onto a well floured surface and continue adding flour a little bit at a time and knead in until you have reached 3.5 to 4 cups total (depending on the humidity). You can stop adding flour when it becomes fairly stiff but still pliable enough to knead. Knead the dough for 8 minutes total.", "name": "In a large bowl combine 2 cups of the flour and the salt. Stir to combine. Add the frothy yeast water and stir well until everything is evenly mixed. Continue adding flour 1/2 cup at a time until it is too hard to stir by hand (about one cup later). Turn the dough out onto a well floured surface and continue adding flour a little bit at a time and knead in until you have reached 3.5 to 4 cups total (depending on the humidity). You can stop adding flour when it becomes fairly stiff but still pliable enough to knead. Knead the dough for 8 minutes total.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/cinnamon-raisin-bagels/#wprm-recipe-33514-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "After kneading, flatten the dough slightly and add the cinnamon and raisins down the center. Fold the dough over and knead a few more times until the raisins are even throughout the dough and the cinnamon has given the dough a swirly appearance. The raisins and cinnamon may \u201cbreak out\u201d of the dough while you knead it in but just keep going and let the dough pick it back up as you knead.", "name": "After kneading, flatten the dough slightly and add the cinnamon and raisins down the center. Fold the dough over and knead a few more times until the raisins are even throughout the dough and the cinnamon has given the dough a swirly appearance. The raisins and cinnamon may \u201cbreak out\u201d of the dough while you knead it in but just keep going and let the dough pick it back up as you knead.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/cinnamon-raisin-bagels/#wprm-recipe-33514-step-0-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Form the dough into a ball, loosely cover and let it rise until double (about 45 min.). Punch the down down, form it into a log and cut it into 10 pieces (for medium bagels). Form each piece into a ball by pulling the dough back and under itself. When you have a smooth ball, pinch it in the center to make the hole then carefully stretch the hole until it is a couple inches across. Make the hole about 3x larger than you think it should be because the dough will puff up quite a bit during cooking and close the hole off. Form the rest of the bagels in the same manner.", "name": "Form the dough into a ball, loosely cover and let it rise until double (about 45 min.). Punch the down down, form it into a log and cut it into 10 pieces (for medium bagels). Form each piece into a ball by pulling the dough back and under itself. When you have a smooth ball, pinch it in the center to make the hole then carefully stretch the hole until it is a couple inches across. Make the hole about 3x larger than you think it should be because the dough will puff up quite a bit during cooking and close the hole off. Form the rest of the bagels in the same manner.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/cinnamon-raisin-bagels/#wprm-recipe-33514-step-0-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the formed bagels on a baking sheet covered with parchment paper and cornmeal or non-stick spray. Let rise until double in size (about 45 minutes). Let rise until double in size (about 45 minutes). While you wait for it to boil, place the tray of bagels under the broiler for one minute. Pull the bagels out, carefully turn them over then place them back in to broil on the second side. Every oven is different so watch the bagels closely. You do not want them to brown just turn slightly dull on the surface.", "name": "Put a large pot of water on to boil. When the water has come to a full, rolling boil, drop the bagels in a few at a time. Boil the bagels for one minute, flip them over and boil for another minute on the opposite side. I found that a long chopstick works well for flipping them in the boiling water.", "name": "Once the bagels have broiled on both sides, turn the oven to 375 to preheat. When the water has come to a full, rolling boil, drop the bagels in a few at a time. Boil the bagels for one minute, flip them over and boil for another minute on the opposite side. Just six simple ingredients! FULL RECIPE BELOW. \ud83d\udc47\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/sheet-pan-kielbasa-potatoes-and-green-beans/\n\n\nINGREDIENTS\n24 oz. petite red potatoes ($2.99)\n12 oz. kielbasa ($4.69)\n1 yellow onion ($0.32)\n12 oz. frozen green beans ($1.00)\n2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.32)\n1/2 Tbsp steak seasoning ($0.15)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. Wash and slice the potatoes into 1-inch pieces. Slice the kielbasa into medallions. Dice the onion into 1-inch pieces.\n2. Add the potatoes, kielbasa, onion, and frozen green beans (no need to thaw) to a large baking sheet. Drizzle with olive oil and sprinkle the steak seasoning over top. Use your hands to toss the ingredients until everything is coated in oil and spices.\n3. Transfer the baking sheet to the oven and roast in the oven for 20 minutes, then give the ingredients on the sheet pan a good stir. Roast for an additional 15 minutes, or until the ingredients achieve the level of browning you desire. Serve hot.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:12 Chop Ingredients\n0:15 Add Oil and Seasoning\n0:27 Bake\n0:30 Finished Meal\n0:36 Serve", "uploadDate": "2020-11-15T16:00:12+00:00", "duration": "PT50S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/LWtrwRE4ARk/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/LWtrwRE4ARk?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LWtrwRE4ARk", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT35M", "totalTime": "PT45M", "recipeIngredient": ["24 oz. petite red potatoes ($2.99)", "12 oz. kielbasa ($4.69)", "1  yellow onion ($0.32)", "12 oz. frozen green beans ($1.00)", "2 Tbsp olive oil  ($0.32)", "1/2 Tbsp steak seasoning ($0.15)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. Also great for the grill!", "datePublished": "2016-02-21T11:46:21+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Cilantro-Lime-Chicken-Drumsticks-close-1.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Cilantro-Lime-Chicken-Drumsticks-close-1-500x480.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Cilantro-Lime-Chicken-Drumsticks-close-1-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Cilantro-Lime-Chicken-Drumsticks-close-1-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Cilantro Lime Chicken", "description": "The bright and vibrant flavors of this Cilantro Lime Chicken are perfect for summer! Bake the chicken in the oven or toss it on the grill! FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/2016/02/cilantro-lime-chicken-drumsticks/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n 2 Tbsp olive oil \n4 cloves garlic, minced \n1/2 tsp cumin \n1/2 tsp salt \nFreshly cracked pepper\n2 limes\n1/2 bunch cilantro\n6 chicken drumsticks (about 1.75 lbs.) \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Combine the olive oil, minced garlic, cumin, salt, and some freshly cracked pepper (about 10-15 cranks of a mill) in a bowl.\n2. Use a zester, microplane, or small-holed cheese grater to remove the zest from one of the limes. Add about 1 tsp zest and 3 Tbsp juice to the marinade.Pull the leaves from 1/4 bunch of cilantro and chop finely. Add the chopped cilantro to the marinade and stir to combine. The other 1/4 bunch of cilantro will be added after baking.\n3. Pour the marinade into a gallon sized zip top bag and add the chicken drumsticks. Close the bag tightly and massage to mix and coat the chicken pieces in the marinade. Refrigerate for 30 minutes, or longer if desired, turning the bag occasionally to redistribute the marinade.\n4. When ready to bake, preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Add the chicken pieces to a casserole dish so they are all in one layer, trying not to overcrowd. Pour the rest of the marinade in the bag over the chicken.\n5. Bake the chicken for 40-45 minutes, basting once or twice throughout. For more browning, turn the broiler on at the end of the cooking time and broil for 2-4 minutes, or until the desired amount of browning is achieved. The total cooking time will ultimately depend on the size of your drumsticks and how closely they are packed together in the baking dish. Use a meat thermometer to make sure the meat has reached 160\u00baF to be sure.\n6. Garnish the chicken with fresh slices of lime and more chopped cilantro leaves.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2017-07-26T18:20:15+00:00", "duration": "PT1M1S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/-gvKaTFveqg/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/-gvKaTFveqg?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-gvKaTFveqg", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["3", "3 to 4 servings"], "prepTime": "PT45M", "cookTime": "PT45M", "totalTime": "PT90M", "recipeIngredient": ["2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.24)", "4 cloves garlic, minced ($0.24)", "1/2 tsp cumin ($0.10)", "1/2 tsp salt ($0.02)", "Freshly cracked pepper ($0.05)", "2  limes ($0.66)", "1/2  bunch cilantro ($0.40)", "6  chicken drumsticks (about 1.75 lbs.) Thank you thank you!!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Kari"}, "datePublished": "2020-07-25"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Easy and tasty. My lines were past their prime zest-wise, so I only used the juice but the sauce was still sooooo good.  I skipped the baggie (let's reduce plastic use, please!) and just rubbed the marinade on the drumsticks and let them marinate in the Pyrex container that I baked them in.  Since I skipped the zest, I couldn't resist sprinkling some Taj\u00edn over the drumsticks after rubing in the marinade, for a little color and to boost the lime flavor. So yeah, I realize I modified the recipe slightly to work with what I had in my pantry, but I'm sure it would have been just as delicious if I'd used the zest and skipped the Taj\u00edn too.  Served with Jasmine rice, Mexican black beans, and Chile spiced roasted butternut. I doubled the amount of oil, lime juice, and cilantro and it was still barely enough to cover four bone-in chicken thighs with legs attached. Secondly, what is the point of the plastic bag? All the pesto just sticks to the bag! Why not just coat the chicken parts with the pesto and then put in a covered bowl to marinate in the refrigerator? Add both to a medium sauce pot with the olive oil and saut\u00e9 over medium heat for 2-3 minutes, or until the onions are soft and transparent.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/coconut-jerk-peas-pineapple-salsa/#wprm-recipe-30252-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the peas to the pot along with the water and 1 Tbsp of jerk seasoning. Stir to combine. Place a lid on the pot, turn the heat to medium-high, and allow it to come to a boil. Stir to combine. Place a lid on the pot, turn the heat to medium-high, and allow it to come to a boil. Once it reaches a boil, turn the heat down to medium-low, and let it simmer for 15 minutes, or until the peas are very tender.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/coconut-jerk-peas-pineapple-salsa/#wprm-recipe-30252-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "While the peas are simmering, prepare the pineapple salsa. Chop the pineapple into very small pieces. Finely dice the red onion. Pull the cilantro leaves from their stems and give them a rough chop. Combine the pineapple, onion, cilantro, juice from half the lime, and salt in a bowl. Stir to combine, then taste, and adjust the lime or salt if needed. Set the salsa aside.", "name": "While the peas are simmering, prepare the pineapple salsa. Chop the pineapple into very small pieces. Finely dice the red onion. Pull the cilantro leaves from their stems and give them a rough chop. Combine the pineapple, onion, cilantro, juice from half the lime, and salt in a bowl. Stir to combine, then taste, and adjust the lime or salt if needed. Set the salsa aside.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/coconut-jerk-peas-pineapple-salsa/#wprm-recipe-30252-step-0-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once the peas are very tender, turn the heat down to low, and add the coconut milk. Stir and heat through. Smash some of the peas against the side of the pot to help thicken the mixture. Taste the peas and add more jerk seasoning and salt until they are very well seasoned. You want the peas to be heavily seasoned because once they're poured over the plain rice, the seasoning will seem diluted.", "name": "Once the peas are very tender, turn the heat down to low, and add the coconut milk. Stir and heat through. Smash some of the peas against the side of the pot to help thicken the mixture. Taste the peas and add more jerk seasoning and salt until they are very well seasoned. Stir until they're very well combined. Add 1 Tbsp of olive oil and 3/4 cups water. Stir until the dough forms a ball. If there is still dry flour on the bottom of the bowl or the dough doesn't form a single, cohesive ball of dough, add more water, 1 Tbsp at a time until the dough comes together. Perfect for fast weeknight dinners!  FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/sweet-and-spicy-glazed-chicken-thighs/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1/4 cup brown sugar \n1/2 tsp cayenne pepper \n1/2 tsp garlic powder\n1/2 tsp paprika \n1/2 tsp salt \nfreshly cracked pepper \n1 Tbsp olive oil \n1.5 lbs. boneless, skinless chicken thighs (4-5 pieces) \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. In a small bowl, combine the brown sugar, cayenne pepper, garlic powder, paprika, salt, and some freshly cracked pepper (10-15 cranks of a pepper mill). \n2. Place the chicken thighs on a cutting board and pat dry with a paper towel. Sprinkle the brown sugar mixture over the chicken, coating both sides liberally.\n3. Heat a large skillet over medium. Once hot, add the olive oil and swirl to coat. Add the coated chicken and cook for about 5-7 minutes on each side, or until cooked through and the brown sugar has turned into a deep brown glaze. Serve hot.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2018-11-25T15:14:33+00:00", "duration": "PT59S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/PLd2voZudMg/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/PLd2voZudMg?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PLd2voZudMg", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT25M", "recipeIngredient": ["1/4 cup brown sugar ($0.12)", "1/2 tsp cayenne pepper ($0.05)", "1/2 tsp garlic powder ($0.05)", "1/2 tsp paprika ($0.05)", "1/2 tsp salt ($0.02)", "freshly cracked pepper ($0.05)", "1 Tbsp olive oil ($0.16)", "1.5 lbs. boneless, skinless chicken thighs (4-5 pieces) ($4.49)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a small bowl, combine the brown sugar, cayenne pepper, garlic powder, paprika, salt, and some freshly cracked pepper (10-15 cranks of a pepper mill).&nbsp;", "name": "In a small bowl, combine the brown sugar, cayenne pepper, garlic powder, paprika, salt, and some freshly cracked pepper (10-15 cranks of a pepper mill).&nbsp;", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/sweet-and-spicy-glazed-chicken-thighs/#wprm-recipe-39064-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the chicken thighs on a cutting board and pat dry with a paper towel. I've been using tzatziki sauce in place of salad dressing for a while now since I found it at the local grocery store and I can't believe it never crossed my mind to use it in a pasta salad. We also substituted bell peppers for the cucumber, because I think it holds up better over the week. I'll probably add cucumber to mine day-of. Also added a can of rinsed garbanzo beans, but left out the red onion.\r\n\r\nTo make it more of a meal, I marinated 1.3 lbs skinless boneless chicken thighs in a marinade of some of the extra ingredients I had (~ 1/2 cup lemon juice, 1/2 cup olive oil, 1 clove minced garlic, lemon zest, salt and ground pepper). Baked these off, and topped the salad servings with the diced chicken later in the day - so basically a half a thigh per serving. Perfect, crispy bacon in the oven every time. FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nGet recipe FAQs, and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-cook-bacon-in-the-oven/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n12 oz. thick-cut bacon\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. Prepare a large baking sheet by lining it with aluminum foil and then placing one or two wire racks on top to hold the bacon above the surface of the baking sheet.\n2. Lay the strips of bacon across the wire rack so they are close, but not overlapping.\n3. Bake the bacon in the fully preheated oven, for 20-25 minutes*, or until it has reached your desired level of crispiness. Begin checking the bacon at 15 minutes, as ovens can vary.\n4. After baking, use tongs to remove the strips of bacon from the wire rack to a paper towel-lined plate. Serve immediately.\n5. Allow the remaining bacon grease to cool for about ten minutes, then pour off into a bowl or jar, and reserve for another use.\n\nNOTES\n*Cooking time can vary depending on the nuances of your oven, and the thickness of your bacon. The times suggested are for thick-cut bacon. If using regular bacon, begin checking the bacon at 10 minutes, and add time as needed to reach your desired level of crispiness.\nCheck your bacon's packaging for nutritional data, as each brand will vary.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here. https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:08 Line baking sheet with foil and wire rack\n0:11 Lay bacon strips on wire rack\n0:15 Bake at 400 degrees for 20-25 mins\n0:17 Remove from oven\n0:18 Add to plate covered with paper towel and enjoy!", "uploadDate": "2022-05-01T15:00:59+00:00", "duration": "PT33S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/DybKbVyU0QE/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/DybKbVyU0QE?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DybKbVyU0QE", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["10", "10 slices"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeIngredient": ["12 oz. thick cut bacon"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. Perfect for meal prep!&nbsp;", "datePublished": "2018-08-23T13:11:10+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/Spinach-and-Feta-Turkey-Meatballs-plated.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/Spinach-and-Feta-Turkey-Meatballs-plated-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/Spinach-and-Feta-Turkey-Meatballs-plated-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/Spinach-and-Feta-Turkey-Meatballs-plated-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Spinach and Feta Turkey Meatballs", "description": "Spinach and Feta Turkey Meatballs are an easy way to add flavor and protein to your meal using inexpensive ground turkey. Perfect for meal prep! FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/spinach-and-feta-turkey-meatballs/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n4 oz. fresh spinach \n2 Tbsp olive oil, divided\n1 lb. lean ground turkey (93% lean) \n1/2 cup breadcrumbs\n1/4 tsp garlic powder\nFreshly cracked pepper \n1/4 tsp salt \n1 large egg \n2 oz. feta, crumbled\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Roughly Chop the spinach. Heat a large skillet over medium, then add 1 Tbsp olive oil. Add the chopped spinach and a pinch of salt. Saut\u00e9 the spinach until it has fully wilted, then remove it from the heat.\n2. While the spinach is saut\u00e9ing, stir together the breadcrumbs, garlic powder, freshly cracked pepper (5 or 6 cranks of a pepper mill), and salt in a large bowl. Lightly whisk the egg, then add the egg, ground turkey, saut\u00e9ed spinach, and crumbled feta to the bowl with the breadcrumbs. Use your hands to combine these ingredients until evenly mixed.\n3. Shape the meat mixture into balls, about one heaping tablespoon each. You should get approximately 24 meatballs.\n4. Wipe out the skillet used for the spinach, add another tablespoon of oil, and heat the skillet once again over medium. Once hot, swirl the oil in the skillet to make sure the surface is coated, then add half of the meatballs. Cook the meatballs for about a minute to a minute and a half on each side, or until the meatballs are well browned and cooked through (about 6-8 minutes total). Remove the cooked meatballs to a clean bowl and repeat with the second batch.\n5. Serve your cooked meatballs with your favorite sauce, over pasta, rice, or roasted vegetables.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-08-15T21:47:51+00:00", "duration": "PT1M1S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/ZHmTv6UULfA/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/ZHmTv6UULfA?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZHmTv6UULfA", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4", "4 5-6 meatballs each"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeIngredient": ["4 oz. fresh spinach ($1.67)", "2 Tbsp olive oil, divided ($0.32)", "1 lb. lean ground turkey (93% lean) ($4.49)", "1/2 cup breadcrumbs ($0.24)", "1/4 tsp garlic powder ($0.02)", "Freshly cracked pepper ($0.02)", "1/4 tsp salt ($0.02)", "1 large egg ($0.22)", "2 oz. feta, crumbled ($0.83)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roughly Chop the spinach. This is the first review I've left.  I have been making these for YEARS; these are my \"you had a baby/moved/surgery\" meal I make for others, and often for my family.  Every single person over many years who tried them has asked for the recipe.  Every single one!  That says something.  I have made them stovetop, oven and crockpot method- stovetop is best, oven okay but soft, crockpot falls apart but still delicious.  Make the recipe as is, don't fiddle.  Make twice as much as you planned and it still won't be enough.  Freezes awesome, flavor grows while frozen in some magical way. Use a cheese marinara sauce if you can find it. Then, let it rest at room temperature for 15-20 minutes. Bring it to a gentle simmer. (We are purposely making the beef broth more concentrated for this recipe.) Keep it warm on the stovetop while you prepare the meat and veggies.", "name": "Simmer", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/pot-roast/#wprm-recipe-100767-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Drizzle olive oil in your dutch oven/roasting vessel of choice and heat on medium high on your largest stovetop burner. Once hot, add carrots and onions. Stir the carrots around every couple of minutes and sear the onion on all sides for approximately 8 minutes total. You want to see some color on those veggies! An easy, fast, and delicious weeknight dinner!", "datePublished": "2020-01-26T18:51:21+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Roasted-Broccoli-Pasta-with-Lemon-and-Feta-bowl.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Roasted-Broccoli-Pasta-with-Lemon-and-Feta-bowl-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Roasted-Broccoli-Pasta-with-Lemon-and-Feta-bowl-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Roasted-Broccoli-Pasta-with-Lemon-and-Feta-bowl-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Roasted Broccoli Pasta with Lemon and Feta", "description": "Roasted Broccoli Pasta with Lemon and Feta is an incredibly simple pasta dish with big flavors. An easy, fast, and delicious weeknight dinner! FULL RECIPE BELOW. \ud83d\udc47\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/roasted-broccoli-pasta-with-lemon-and-feta/ \n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 lb. broccoli crowns ($1.79)\n1 Tbsp olive oil ($0.16)\n1 tsp steak seasoning ($0.10)\n1 fresh lemon ($0.39)\n8 oz. whole wheat penne pasta ($0.50)\n2 Tbsp butter ($0.20)\n1 oz. crumbled feta ($0.55)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. Cut the broccoli into small florets. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper, then spread the florets out over the baking sheet. Drizzle the broccoli with olive oil and sprinkle the steak seasoning over top. Toss the broccoli until it is well coated in oil and seasoning.\n2. Roast the broccoli for 20-25 minutes, or until it is brown and crispy on the edges.\n3. While the broccoli is roasting, prepare the rest of the dish. Bring a pot of water to boil for the penne. Once boiling, add the pasta, and continue to boil until the pasta is tender (8-10 minutes). Reserve about \u00bd cup of the starchy pasta water, then drain the pasta in a colander.\n4. While the pasta is boiling, zest a lemon, then cut it into wedges.\n5. Return the drained pasta to the pot (heat turned off). Add the roasted broccoli florets, the butter, about 1 tsp lemon zest, and the juice from two of the lemon wedges. Stir the ingredients together, letting the residual heat from the pasta melt the butter. If the pasta seems too dry, add a splash or two of the reserved pasta water.\n6. Top the pasta with crumbled feta and a pinch or two more steak seasoning, if desired. Serve with extra lemon wedges.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/ \n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTimestamp:\n0:00 Intro\n0:08 Cut broccoli and place on baking tray\n0:13 Drizzle with olive oil and seasoning\n0:19 Toss to coat\n0:21 Roast at 400 for 25 minutes\n0:24 Meanwhile boil pasta\n0:29 Reserve one cup pasta water\n0:32 Drain pasta and add roasted broccoli\n0:34 Add butter, lemon zest, lemon juice, pasta water and stir\n0:42 Sprinkle with feta and serve!", "uploadDate": "2020-09-13T17:30:24+00:00", "duration": "PT56S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/MJMTXRMj5bQ/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/MJMTXRMj5bQ?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MJMTXRMj5bQ", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT40M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 lb. broccoli crowns ($1.79)", "1 Tbsp olive oil ($0.16)", "1 tsp steak seasoning ($0.10)", "1  fresh lemon ($0.39)", "8 oz. whole wheat penne pasta ($0.50)", "2 Tbsp butter ($0.20)", "1 oz. crumbled feta ($0.55)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/2016/02/5-minute-nacho-cheese-sauce/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n2 Tbsp butter \n2 Tbsp flour \n1 cup whole milk \n6 oz. medium cheddar, shredded (about 1.5 cups) \n1/4 tsp salt \n1/4 tsp chili powder\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Add the butter and flour to a small sauce pot. Heat and whisk the butter and flour together until they become bubbly and foamy. Continue to cook and whisk the bubbly mixture for about 60 seconds.\n2. Whisk the milk into the flour and butter mixture. Turn the heat up slightly and allow the milk to come to a simmer while whisking. When it reaches a simmer, the mixture will thicken. Once it's thick enough to coat a spoon, turn off the heat.\n3. Stir in the shredded cheddar, one handful at a time, until melted into the sauce. If needed, place the pot over a low flame to help the cheese melt. Do not over heat the cheese sauce.\n4. Once all the cheese is melted into the sauce, stir in the salt and chili powder. Taste and adjust the seasoning as needed. If the sauce becomes too thick, simply whisk in an additional splash of milk.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2018-01-21T18:05:41+00:00", "duration": "PT1M5S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/5DSDRUlbMxo/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/5DSDRUlbMxo?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5DSDRUlbMxo", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["6", "6 (1/4 cup each)"], "cookTime": "PT5M", "totalTime": "PT5M", "recipeIngredient": ["2 Tbsp butter  ($0.28)", "2 Tbsp flour  ($0.02)", "1 cup whole milk  ($0.19)", "6 oz. medium cheddar, shredded (about 1.5 cups) ($2.25)", "1/4 tsp salt  ($0.02)", "1/4 tsp chili powder  ($0.02)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the butter and flour to a small sauce pot. It&#39;s the ultimate homemade brownie recipe!", "datePublished": "2022-04-23T08:42:22+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Homemade-Brownies-stack.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Homemade-Brownies-stack-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Homemade-Brownies-stack-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Homemade-Brownies-stack-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Super Fudgy Homemade Brownies", "description": "These super fudgy homemade brownies are thick, rich, extra-chocolatey, and super moist. They're the ultimate homemade fudge brownie! FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47 \n\nGet recipe FAQs, substitutions, and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/super-fudgy-homemade-brownies/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n12 Tbsp butter (salted) ($1.32)\n2 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.08)\n3/4 cup unsweetened cocoa powder ($0.42)\n1 1/4 cup granulated sugar ($0.20)\n2 large eggs ($0.42)\n2 tsp vanilla extract ($0.56)\n1/4 tsp salt ($0.01)\n3/4 cup all-purpose flour ($0.05)\n1/2 cup chocolate chips ($0.83)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Preheat the oven to 350\u00baF. Melt the butter in a large bowl in the microwave (or in a sauce pot and then transfer to a bowl).\n2. Add the cooking oil and cocoa powder to the melted butter and whisk until smooth.\n3. Whisk the sugar into the chocolate mixture until evenly incorporated, then whisk in the eggs, vanilla extract, and salt.\n4. Stir in the flour until it forms a thick batter. Finally, fold in the chocolate chips.\n5. Prepare an 8\u00d78-inch baking dish by coating it with butter or non-stick spray, then laying in a piece of parchment paper (the paper does not need to cover all sides of the dish). Add the brownie batter to the prepared dish, then spread it out evenly.\n6. Bake the brownies in the preheated oven for 40 minutes. The brownies will be quite soft and moist, even when fully baked.\n7. Remove the brownies from the oven and let them cool for 10 minutes before lifting them out of the baking dish. Slice into nine pieces and serve.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here. https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIME STAMPS \n0:00 Introduction\n0:03 Melt butter and add cooking oil and cocoa powder and whisk\n0:12 Add sugar, whisk, eggs, vanilla and salt\n0:23 Add flour and stir to combine\n0:30 Add chocolate chips and stir to combine\n0:35 Spread in baking dish & smooth\n0:41 Bake for 40 mins. \n0:44 Cool & Enjoy!", "uploadDate": "2022-08-14T15:00:09+00:00", "duration": "PT58S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/yRlgP1JBFs4/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/yRlgP1JBFs4?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yRlgP1JBFs4", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["9"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT40M", "totalTime": "PT55M", "recipeIngredient": ["12 Tbsp butter (salted) ($1.32)", "2 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.08)", "3/4 cup unsweetened cocoa powder ($0.42)", "1 1/4 cup granulated sugar ($0.20)", "2 large eggs ($0.42)", "2 tsp vanilla extract ($0.56)", "1/4 tsp salt ($0.01)", "3/4 cup all-purpose flour ($0.05)", "1/2 cup chocolate chips ($0.83)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00baF. To the mashed avocado,  I add lemon juice, honey,\r\na sprinkle each of sesame seeds and poppy seeds,  black pepper,  all purpose salt-free seasoning,  and red pepper flakes.  But what really took it to gourmet level for me was my friend's suggestion to add red onion.  I finely dice a quarter or an eighth of an onion,  depending on the size, to add to the mixture.   Then I pile it generously on either sourdough toast or Rustic Italian Oval toast for an amazing Sunday brunch.  I look forward to it all week. FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nGet recipe FAQs and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/easy-pesto-chicken-and-vegetables/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 red bell pepper ($1.50)\n1 zucchini ($0.60)\n1 yellow squash ($0.50)\n1/2 red onion ($0.19)\n1.3 lbs. boneless, skinless chicken breast ($6.67)\n2 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.08)\n1 cup frozen green beans ($0.67)\n1/3 cup pesto* ($0.73)\n1/8 tsp salt* ($0.01)\n1/8 tsp freshly cracked pepper* ($0.01)\n1 Tbsp grated Parmesan* ($0.11)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Chop the bell pepper, yellow squash, and zucchini, and slice the red onion. I like to make different shapes for each vegetable, but aim to make the pieces all around the same size.\n2. Cube the chicken breasts into \u00bd-inch pieces.\n3. Add the cooking oil to a large skillet and heat over medium-high. Once the skillet and oil are very hot, add the chicken and saut\u00e9 until the chicken pieces are opaque (3-5 minutes \u2013 the chicken will continue to cook as you add vegetables).\n4. Add the green beans to the skillet and saut\u00e9 for 1-2 minutes more, or just until thawed.\n5. Add the bell pepper and red onion to the skillet. Saut\u00e9 for 1-2 minutes more. If water is beginning to pool in the skillet, turn the heat up slightly. It should be hot enough that the water released from the vegetables evaporates quickly.\n6. Add the yellow squash and zucchini to the skillet and continue to saut\u00e9 2-3 minutes more, or just until the squash softens slightly.\n7. Turn the heat off, add the pesto to the skillet, and stir until everything is coated. Give the vegetables a taste and add salt, pepper, or more pesto if desired. Top with a light sprinkle of Parmesan just before serving.\nNOTES\n*You may need more or less pesto, salt, pepper, or Parmesan depending on the volume of your vegetables and your personal taste. \n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:06 Chop vegetables\n0:13 Cube chicken\n0:15 Saut\u00e9 chicken\n0:22 Add green beans\n0:25 Add bell pepper and onion\n0:30 Add zucchini and squash\n0:32 Stir in pesto\n0:39 Season with salt, parsley, and Parmesan\n0:47 Pack for meal prep", "uploadDate": "2021-05-23T17:46:40+00:00", "duration": "PT1M1S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/RQZNyz0koGQ/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/RQZNyz0koGQ?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RQZNyz0koGQ", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4", "4 1.5 cups each"], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeIngredient": ["1  red bell pepper ($1.50)", "1  zucchini ($0.60)", "1  yellow squash ($0.50)", "1/2  red onion ($0.19)", "1.3 lbs. boneless, skinless chicken breast ($6.67)", "2 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.08)", "1 cup frozen green beans ($0.67)", "1/3 cup pesto* ($0.73)", "1/8 tsp salt* ($0.01)", "1/8 tsp freshly cracked pepper* ($0.01)", "1 Tbsp grated Parmesan* ($0.11)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Chop the bell pepper, yellow squash, and zucchini, and slice the red onion. Plus, leftovers reheat beautifully!", "datePublished": "2019-05-14T18:20:01+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Spicy-Orecchiette-with-Chicken-Sausage-and-Kale-bowl-above.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Spicy-Orecchiette-with-Chicken-Sausage-and-Kale-bowl-above-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Spicy-Orecchiette-with-Chicken-Sausage-and-Kale-bowl-above-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Spicy-Orecchiette-with-Chicken-Sausage-and-Kale-bowl-above-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Spicy Orecchiette with Chicken Sausage", "description": "Spicy Orecchiette with Chicken Sausage and Kale is a fast, easy, and filling weeknight dinner that will always satisfy. Plus, leftovers reheat beautifully! FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/spicy-orecchiette-with-chicken-sausage-and-kale/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n8 oz. orecchiette \n2 Tbsp olive oil \n12 oz. chicken sausage \n2 Tbsp butter \n2 cloves garlic, minced\n8 oz. chopped kale* \n1/4 cup grated Parmesan \n1/4 tsp crushed red pepper \n1 pinch salt \nfreshly cracked pepper to taste\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Cook the orecchiette according to the package directions. Before draining the orecchiette in a colander, reserve about 1/3 cup of the starchy pasta water.\n2. While the orecchiette is cooking, begin preparing the rest of the recipe. Slice the chicken sausage into medallions.\n3. Add the olive oil and chicken sausage to a large pot and saut\u00e9 over medium until the chicken sausage begins to brown (about 5 minutes).\n4. Add the minced garlic and butter to the pot with the sausage and continue to saut\u00e9 for one more minute.\n5. Next, add the chopped kale and reserved pasta water. Turn the heat down to medium-low and continue to cook and stir until the kale has wilted (about 2-3 minutes). Use your spoon to dissolve any browned bits off the bottom of the pot as you stir.\n6. Remove the pot from the heat and stir in the cooked and drained orecchiette. If the pasta and kale are still steaming heavily, let the contents of the pot cool for about 5 minutes, stirring occasionally to release steam. You want the Parmesan to coat the pasta, but not melt.\n7. Once the pasta and kale is hot, but not steaming, add the grated Parmesan, crushed red pepper, salt, and about 15-20 cranks of a pepper mill. Stir to combine, then taste and add more salt if needed. Serve warm.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-08-24T21:24:45+00:00", "duration": "PT57S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/EfMb5cpx568/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/EfMb5cpx568?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EfMb5cpx568", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4", "4 about 1.5 cups each"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT20M", "recipeIngredient": ["8 oz. orecchiette ($1.33)", "2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.32)", "12 oz. chicken sausage ($2.99)", "2 Tbsp butter ($0.27)", "2 cloves garlic, minced ($0.16)", "8 oz. chopped kale* ($2.14)", "1/4 cup grated Parmesan ($0.44)", "1/4 tsp crushed red pepper ($0.02)", "1 pinch salt ($0.02)", "freshly cracked pepper to taste ($0.05)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cook the orecchiette according to the package directions. FULL RECIPE BELOW. \n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-make-stove-top-popcorn/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 Tbsp canola or vegetable oil \n2 Tbsp popcorn kernels \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Add the oil and one kernel to a small sauce pot. Place the lid on top and turn the heat onto medium-high. Wait for the kernel to pop.\n2. Once the kernel has popped, add the rest of the kernels, replace the lid, and give the pot a swirl to coat the kernels in the hot oil. Wait for the kernels to begin to pop. You can swirl again to redistribute the hot oil, if needed.\n3. Once the kernels begin to pop rapidly, crack the lid a little bit to allow excess steam to escape. \n4. Make sure it's only open a little to keep the pot hot enough to continue popping the corn.\n5. When the popping slows to a few seconds between pops, turn off the heat. Wait a few extra seconds for the last few pops, then remove the lid and season the popcorn. Enjoy!\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2015-11-23T22:08:00+00:00", "duration": "PT1M43S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/pLCDzYmriuc/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/pLCDzYmriuc?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pLCDzYmriuc", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4", "4 2 cups each"], "cookTime": "PT5M", "totalTime": "PT5M", "recipeIngredient": ["2 Tbsp high heat cooking oil* ($0.04)", "1/3 cup popcorn kernels ($0.19)", "2 Tbsp butter (optional) ($0.26)", "1/2 tsp seasoning salt (optional) ($0.05)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the oil and one kernel to a large sauce pot. I followed that as written and got a batch that was half burned, yet also had a significant number of unpopped kernels.\r\n\r\nHere's one I found on my hard drive that I appear to have written myself in 2019 that I *thought* was much the same as this one, but isn't. It's the same basic idea but gets much better results.\r\n\r\nBASIC STOVETOP POPCORN\r\n\r\nIngredients:\r\n2 tablespoons canola (or similar) oil\r\n1/2 cup popcorn\r\nSeasonings to taste\r\n\r\nOther equipment:\r\nDutch oven or similar sized pot with decent lid. Bottom of the pot MUST be flat or you'll get a lot of burned and/or unpopped kernels. Do not use a pot with visible curvature.\r\n\r\nPreparation:\r\nPut oil and 2-3 kernels of popcorn in pot. Cover most of the way and put on medium-high heat until these kernels pop.\r\n\r\nAdd remaining kernels, give the pot a shake to cover them in oil, and place lid on pot, leaving a small crack for steam. If melted butter is among your desired seasonings, NOW is the time to start melting it. Once kernels start popping, shake the pot almost constantly to avoid burning any and minimize unpopped kernels. Remove from heat when you can count to 5 without hearing a pop.\r\n\r\nAdd seasonings to pot, replace lid and hold it down tightly, and shake vigorously. \r\n\r\nTransfer to a large bowl and serve immediately.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Jeff"}, "datePublished": "2025-10-21"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Easy peasy! It's always enjoyed by my family, too. My mother usually used all canned beans: green beans, yellow wax beans, and kidney beans. We did, however, have freshly cooked ones in the summer. Wax beans can be hard to find these days, but I sometimes use garbanzos as one of the 3 options, or even pintos, my favorite bean due to its mild taste and creamy texture--whatever is in the pantry. A spice lover, I've been known to add some minced jalapeno. Mom never used oil in her dressing--although I like to add dab to mellow the vinegar--or salt as the canned beans are plenty salty. Olive oil wasn't used much in rural parts of our country back in the 1950s--probably not even available in our very small town grocery store. FULL RECIPE BELOW. \ud83d\udc47\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/swamp-soup/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n3 cloves garlic ($0.24)\n1 yellow onion ($0.32)\n1/2 lb. carrots (about 4 medium) ($0.30)\n3 ribs celery ($0.46)\n2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.32)\n1 Tbsp dried basil ($0.30)\n1 Tbsp dried oregano ($0.30)\n3 8oz. cans tomato sauce ($0.75)\n3 15oz. cans diced tomatoes ($1.35)\n1.5 cups vegetable broth ($0.20)\n1 10oz. pkg frozen chopped spinach ($0.99)\n8 oz. Swiss cheese ($1.69)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Mince the garlic, dice the onion, peel and slice the carrots, and slice the celery. Add the onion, garlic, carrots, and celery to a large soup pot with the olive oil and saut\u00e9 over medium heat for about five minutes, or until the onions are soft.\n2. Add the tomato sauce, diced tomatoes (with juices), vegetable broth, basil, and oregano to the pot. Stir to combine, then allow the soup to come to a simmer.\n3. Once the soup is simmering, add the frozen spinach (no need to thaw). Stir the spinach into the hot soup until it has melted and heated through.\n4. Once the spinach is thoroughly mixed into the soup, give the soup a taste and add salt if needed. I did not add any, but this will ultimately depend on the sodium content of your canned goods and vegetable broth.\n5. Dice the swiss cheese into small cubes. Add a small handful of cubes to each bowl, then ladle the hot soup over top. Serve and enjoy!\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Intro\n0:06 Saut\u00e9 onion, celery, carrot, and garlic\n0:17 Add tomato sauce and diced tomatoes\n0:21 Add herbs and vegetable broth\n0:29 Simmer\n0:32 Add spinach\n0:40 Add Swiss cheese\n0:40 Serve", "uploadDate": "2020-11-01T14:00:08+00:00", "duration": "PT1M", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/8HORiThFndo/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/8HORiThFndo?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8HORiThFndo", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["8", "8 about 1.25 cups each"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeIngredient": ["3 cloves garlic  ($0.12)", "1  yellow onion  ($0.70)", "1/2 lb. carrots  (about 4 medium, $0.49)", "3 ribs celery  ($0.63)", "2 Tbsp olive oil  ($0.44)", "1 Tbsp dried basil  ($0.30)", "1 Tbsp dried oregano  ($0.30)", "3 8oz. cans tomato sauce  ($1.59)", "3 15oz. cans diced tomatoes  ($3.18)", "1.5 cups vegetable broth ($0.14)", "1 10oz. pkg frozen chopped spinach  ($1.34)", "8 oz.
