FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47\n\nGet recipe FAQs and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/greek-turkey-burgers/\n\nShown with Super Fresh Cucumber Salad: https://www.budgetbytes.com/super-fresh-cucmber-salad/\n\nINGREDIENTS\nLEMON DILL YOGURT SAUCE\n1/2 cup plain Greek yogurt ($0.50)\n1/2 Tbsp lemon juice ($0.03)\n1/8 tsp garlic powder ($0.02)\n1/8 tsp dried dill ($0.02)\n1/8 tsp salt ($0.02)\nTURKEY BURGERS\n19 oz. ground turkey* ($3.89)\n1/4 cup sun dried tomatoes ($0.83)\n1/4 cup minced red onion ($0.08)\n2 oz. frozen spinach (1 cup when frozen) ($0.25)\n1/4 cup crumbled feta ($0.57)\n1 tsp dried oregano ($0.10)\n1/4 tsp garlic powder ($0.02)\n1/4 tsp salt ($0.02)\n1 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.04)\nFOR SERVING\n5 hamburger buns ($3.04)\n1/2 cucumber, sliced ($0.75)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Make the lemon dill yogurt sauce first. Stir together the Greek yogurt, lemon juice, garlic powder, dried dill, and salt. Refrigerate until ready to use.\n2. Prepare the add-ins for the turkey burgers. Finely chop the sun dried tomatoes, mince or finely dice the red onion, crumble the feta, and then thaw and squeeze all the moisture out of the frozen spinach (2 oz. will be about 1 cup when frozen, \u00bc cup when thawed and squeezed dry).\n3. Add the ground turkey, sun dried tomatoes, red onion, feta, spinach, dried oregano, garlic powder, and salt to a bowl. Mix the ingredients together until evenly combined.\n4. Divide and shape the turkey mixture into five burger patties. Make them flatter and wider than usual because they will shrink up and in as they cook.\n5. Heat \u00bd Tbsp cooking oil in a skillet over medium. Once hot, add three of the turkey burgers and cook for 5-7 minutes on each side, or until browned and cooked through. Repeat with the remaining cooking oil and the rest of the burger patties.\n6. To serve, smear some of the lemon dill yogurt sauce on a bun. Add a turkey burger, some sliced cucumber, and sliced red onion, then enjoy.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:09 Make yogurt dill sauce\n0:20 Season ground turkey\n0:28 Mix and shape burgers\n0:34 Cook turkey burgers\n0:46 Dress burgers\n0:53 Serve and enjoy!", "uploadDate": "2021-05-09T17:03:52+00:00", "duration": "PT1M", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/fJAnAli32uE/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/fJAnAli32uE?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fJAnAli32uE", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["5"], "prepTime": "PT30M", "cookTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT45M", "recipeIngredient": ["1/2 cup plain Greek yogurt ($0.50)", "1/2 Tbsp lemon juice ($0.03)", "1/8 tsp garlic powder ($0.02)", "1/8 tsp dried dill ($0.02)", "1/8 tsp salt ($0.02)", "19 oz. ground turkey (see notes, $3.89)", "1/4 cup sun dried tomatoes ($0.83)", "1/4 cup minced red onion ($0.08)", "2 oz. frozen spinach (1 cup when frozen, $0.25)", "1/4 cup crumbled feta ($0.57)", "1 tsp dried oregano ($0.10)", "1/4 tsp garlic powder ($0.02)", "1/4 tsp salt ($0.02)", "1 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.04)", "5  hamburger buns ($3.04)", "1/2  cucumber (sliced, $0.75)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Make the lemon dill yogurt sauce first. FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47 \n\nGet recipe FAQs, substitutions, and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/baked-chicken-wings/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 Tbsp cornstarch ($0.03)\n1/2 tsp paprika ($0.05)\n1/2 tsp smoked paprika ($0.05)\n1/2 tsp garlic powder ($0.05)\n1/4 tsp onion powder ($0.03)\n1/8 tsp cayenne pepper ($0.03)\n1/4 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.02)\n1/2 tsp salt ($0.03)\n1 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.08)\n2.5 lbs. chicken wings or drumettes ($9.98)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. In a small bowl, combine the cornstarch, paprika, smoked paprika, garlic powder, onion powder, cayenne, pepper, and salt.\n2. Pat the wings dry, then place them in a bowl. Drizzle the cooking oil over top, then toss until the wings are coated in oil. Add the cornstarch-seasoning mixture, then toss to coat again.\n3. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper for easy cleanup, then place wire cooling racks on top. Place the seasoned chicken wings on the wire racks with space between each wing.\n4. Bake the wings for 30 minutes, then flip and bake for 20-25 minutes, or until the wings have achieved the amount of browning desired (this will depend on the size of your wings).\n5. Serve hot with your favorite sauce!\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here. https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:05 Make seasoning\n0:24 Coat wings in cooking oil\n0:26 Add seasoning\n0:30 Place wings on wire rack \n0:35 Bake \n0:45 Serve and ENJOY!", "uploadDate": "2022-05-29T15:00:10+00:00", "duration": "PT55S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/38szuzx0_0s/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/38szuzx0_0s?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=38szuzx0_0s", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["3", "3 about 4 pieces each"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT55M", "totalTime": "PT65M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 Tbsp cornstarch ($0.03)", "1/2 tsp paprika ($0.05)", "1/2 tsp smoked paprika ($0.05)", "1/2 tsp garlic powder ($0.05)", "1/4 tsp onion powder ($0.03)", "1/8 tsp cayenne pepper ($0.03)", "1/4 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.02)", "1/2 tsp salt ($0.03)", "1 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.08)", "2.5 lbs. chicken wings or drumettes ($9.98)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. Comfort food all in one skillet!&nbsp;", "datePublished": "2017-12-11T09:28:37+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/Vegetable-Pot-Pie-Skillet-bowl-1.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/Vegetable-Pot-Pie-Skillet-bowl-1-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/Vegetable-Pot-Pie-Skillet-bowl-1-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/Vegetable-Pot-Pie-Skillet-bowl-1-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Vegetable Pot Pie Skillet", "description": "This rich and comforting Vegetable Pot Pie Skillet has a homemade biscuit topping and is made faster for weeknight dinners by using frozen vegetables.  FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/vegetable-pot-pie-skillet-cheddar-biscuit-topping/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\nFILLING\n3 Tbsp butter \n1 onion \n3 Tbsp all-purpose flour \n1 cup whole milk \n1/2 tsp salt \n1/4 tsp dried thyme \n1/4 tsp dried sage \nFreshly cracked pepper \n1 cup vegetable broth\n1 lb frozen mixed vegetables* \nCHEDDAR BISCUIT TOPPING\n2 cups all-purpose flour \n3 tsp baking powder \n6 Tbsp cold butter \n1/2 tsp salt \n1 cup shredded cheddar \n2 Tbsp chopped chives (optional)\n1 cup milk \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Dice the onion and add it to a deep, oven safe skillet with 3 Tbsp butter. Saut\u00e9 the onions over medium heat until soft and transparent. Add 3 Tbsp flour and continue to saut\u00e9 for about two minutes. Whisk in one cup milk until no lumps remain. Add the salt, thyme, sage, and some freshly cracked pepper. Allow the milk to come up to a simmer, whisking often, until it thickens.\n2. Whisk in the vegetable broth and allow it to come up to a simmer again. You should now have a thick, creamy sauce. Add the frozen vegetables (no need to thaw) and stir to combine. Turn the heat down to low and allow the mixture to heat through, stirring occasionally, while you prepare the biscuit topping.\n3. Preheat the oven to 425\u00baF. In a large bowl stir together the flour, baking powder, and salt until well combined. Cut the butter into several chunks, add it to the flour mixture, then use your hands or a pastry cutter to work the butter into the flour until the mixture resembles damp sand. Stir in the cheddar and chives.\n4. Add 1 cup milk to the biscuit mixture and stir until a dough forms. If the dough seems is too wet or sticky to work with your hands, simply dust a little more flour on top.\n5. Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface and press it down into a 3/4-inch thick circle, then cut into 6 biscuits (gather up the scraps and reshape to cut more biscuits if needed). Place the biscuits over top of the vegetable pot pie mixture in the skillet.\n6. Bake the skillet for 18-20 minutes, or until the biscuits are golden brown on top and the filling is bubbly around the edges. Serve hot.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2018-09-27T18:44:19+00:00", "duration": "PT1M1S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/AjdGzLy52aA/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/AjdGzLy52aA?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AjdGzLy52aA", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["6"], "prepTime": "PT20M", "cookTime": "PT35M", "totalTime": "PT55M", "recipeIngredient": ["3 Tbsp butter ($0.33)", "1  onion ($0.25)", "3 Tbsp all-purpose flour ($0.03)", "1 cup whole milk ($0.38)", "1/2 tsp salt ($0.02)", "1/4 tsp dried thyme ($0.03)", "1/4 tsp dried sage ($0.03)", "Freshly cracked pepper ($0.05)", "1 cup vegetable broth ($0.14)", "1 lb frozen mixed vegetables* ($0.97)", "2 cups all-purpose flour ($0.19)", "3 tsp baking powder ($0.18)", "6 Tbsp cold butter ($0.66)", "1/2 tsp salt ($0.02)", "1 cup shredded cheddar ($0.94)", "2 Tbsp chopped chives (optional) ($0.32)", "1 cup milk ($0.38)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Dice the onion and add it to a deep, oven safe skillet with 3 Tbsp butter. Saut\u00e9 the onions over medium heat until soft and transparent. Add 3 Tbsp flour and continue to saut\u00e9 for about two minutes. Whisk in one cup milk until no lumps remain. Add the salt, thyme, sage, and some freshly cracked pepper. Allow the milk to come up to a simmer, whisking often, until it thickens.", "name": "Dice the onion and add it to a deep, oven safe skillet with 3 Tbsp butter. Saut\u00e9 the onions over medium heat until soft and transparent. Add 3 Tbsp flour and continue to saut\u00e9 for about two minutes. Whisk in one cup milk until no lumps remain. Add the salt, thyme, sage, and some freshly cracked pepper. Allow the milk to come up to a simmer, whisking often, until it thickens.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/vegetable-pot-pie-skillet-cheddar-biscuit-topping/#wprm-recipe-30470-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk in the vegetable broth and allow it to come up to a simmer again. You should now have a thick, creamy sauce. Add the frozen vegetables (no need to thaw) and stir to combine. Turn the heat down to low and allow the mixture to heat through, stirring occasionally, while you prepare the biscuit topping.", "name": "Whisk in the vegetable broth and allow it to come up to a simmer again. You should now have a thick, creamy sauce. Add the frozen vegetables (no need to thaw) and stir to combine. Turn the heat down to low and allow the mixture to heat through, stirring occasionally, while you prepare the biscuit topping.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/vegetable-pot-pie-skillet-cheddar-biscuit-topping/#wprm-recipe-30470-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 425\u00baF. In a large bowl stir together the flour, baking powder, and salt until well combined. FULL RECIPE BELOW. \ud83d\udc47\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/garlic-butter-baked-cod/\n\nIngredients\n     2 Tbsp butter (room temperature) ($0.26)\n    1 Tbsp olive oil ($0.16)\n    2 cloves garlic, minced ($0.16)\n    1/8 tsp paprika ($0.02)\n    1/8 tsp salt ($0.01)\n    1 Tbsp finely chopped parsley ($0.10)\n    8 oz. cod (two 4 oz. filets) ($2.48)\n    1 fresh lemon ($0.37)\n\nInstructions\n1. Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. In a small bowl, combine the butter, olive oil, garlic, paprika, salt, and chopped parsley. Stir until it forms a fairly smooth paste.\n2. Take a small dollop of the garlic butter and spread it over the surface of a small baking dish to keep the fish from sticking. Add the cod filets to the dish and then coat all sides of the fish with the remaining garlic butter.\n3. Slice half of the lemon and add the lemon slices to the baking dish with the fish. Cut the remaining 1/2 lemon into wedges for serving.\n4. Bake the cod for 20 minutes, or until it flakes easily with a fork and the internal temperature reaches 145\u00baF. Spoon any juices from the bottom of the pan over the fish. Serve the cod immediately with the remaining fresh lemon wedges for squeezing juice over top.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIMESTAMPS\n0:00 Introduction\n0:11 Make Garlic Butter\n0:23 Prepare Baking Dish\n0:27 Place Cod Filets in Baking Dish\n0:29 Coat Cod Filets in Garlic Butter\n0:37 Add Lemon Slices\n0:39 Bake Cod\n0:44 Drizzle Garlic Butter Over Top after Baking\n0:46 Serve", "uploadDate": "2020-11-22T16:45:20+00:00", "duration": "PT59S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/erAO6LTdQpA/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/erAO6LTdQpA?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=erAO6LTdQpA", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeIngredient": ["4 Tbsp butter (room temperature) ($0.50)", "2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.32)", "4 cloves garlic, minced ($0.32)", "1/4 tsp paprika ($0.02)", "1/4 tsp salt ($0.02)", "2 Tbsp finely chopped parsley ($0.22)", "1 lb. cod (4 4 oz. filets) ($5.99)", "1  fresh lemon ($0.69)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 400\u00baF. Add all the ingredients to a blender and pur\u00e9e until smooth.\n2. Serve immediately with fresh cut fruit for dipping, or refrigerate until ready to eat.\n\nNOTES\n*Lemon juice is optional. Let the potatoes fry, without disturbing, until deeply golden brown on the bottom (3-5 minutes). Let the potatoes fry, without disturbing, until deeply golden brown on the bottom (3-5 minutes). It also dirtied way more dishes (and towels!) than my usual breakfast potatoes and made a huge potato-y mess of the kitchen.\r\n I'll be sticking with homefries from here on out, I think!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Amanda"}, "datePublished": "2020-06-24"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "reviewBody": "Definatley cook them in the cast iron!  I take an onion section and grate it on the fine setting of the cheese grater, then mix it in with the grated 'taters before cooking for mmmmm mmm flava.  I don't rinse, or dry, and have no crisping problems. To me, keeping the starch in helps to hold the shape and keep from seperating . Before flipping, I oil down the raw side.  We keep our olive oil in a condiment squeeze  bottle, add just a little before flipping. Top with shredded cheese of choice when done, smoked Gouda rocks.  Serve with side of sliced fried ham and eggs of choice, all cooked in cast iron.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Jim Cochran"}, "datePublished": "2019-12-24"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Ill back burner that then till i get more adventurous LOL. I made these the other morning and it was my first attempt at ever making hashbrowns. By the third batch I was getting really good at knowing when to flip (I grated two jumbo russet potatoes - turns out that makes a LOT of hashbrowns for two people). The rest of the pig was cut up and went to the freezer, except for the hams which were sent to a local German community to be smoked. Move the onions off to the side or scooch them to another spot in the pan. You want the chicken to lie flat in the pan so it gets a good sear on it.", "name": "Brown the chicken", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/braised-chicken-and-peaches/#wprm-recipe-133371-step-0-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove chicken from the pan and cover it off to the side. I started doing these when my grandsons were young and I often had to feed them lunch or supper. I would, however, suggest an egg wash to make the finished calzone really shine. I also make my own pizza dough--so fast, easy, and cheap! There are recipes on this site. I made these for lunch today and shaved almost $4 off Marsha's cost due to making my own dough (with half of my recipe now in the freezer) and a good price on mushrooms. Marsha's step 3 suggestion to precook the veggies is absolutely the best. I do big batches almost weekly--dice 1 large onion, 1 red, orange, or yellow bell pepper, 1 poblano pepper, and plenty of minced garlic--freeze or refrigerate. I usually don't bother to freeze as  I'm certain to use up a batch within days. I do the same with mushrooms, which I like to slice myself as I slice thinner, saute in oil &amp; butter, and add a splash of wine or balsamic vinegar--I almost never have enough left over to freeze, ($2.00)", "1 pinch salt and pepper ($0.05)", "1/2 tsp  smoked paprika (optional) ($0.05)", "1 Tbsp cooking oil ($0.04)", "4 large eggs ($0.93)", "4 slices bacon ($1.00)", "1 15oz. can chickpeas, rinsed and drained ($0.55)", "1 pint grape tomatoes ($1.99)", "4 oz. cheddar (cubed or shredded) ($0.75)", "2 oz. spring mix or baby romaine* ($2.00)", "1/2 cup salad dressing* ($0.71)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cook the chicken first, to ensure it has time to cool before you build your salads. Warm chicken will cause the greens to wilt prematurely. Cover the chicken with plastic, then pound with a rolling pin until it an even thickness. This will help the breast cook evenly. Season both sides of the chicken breast with salt, pepper, and smoked paprika.", "name": "Cook the chicken first, to ensure it has time to cool before you build your salads. Warm chicken will cause the greens to wilt prematurely. Cover the chicken with plastic, then pound with a rolling pin until it an even thickness. This will help the breast cook evenly. Season both sides of the chicken breast with salt, pepper, and smoked paprika.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/cobb-salad-meal-prep/#wprm-recipe-37999-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Heat 1 Tbsp cooking oil in a skillet over medium heat, then swirl to coat the surface of the skillet in oil. Add the chicken to the skillet and cook on each side for 5-7 minutes, or until it is well browned on the outside and cooked through. Transfer the chicken to a clean cutting board, let it rest for five minutes, then dice it into small pieces. Place the chopped chicken in a bowl and refrigerate while you prepare the rest of the ingredients.", "name": "Heat 1 Tbsp cooking oil in a skillet over medium heat, then swirl to coat the surface of the skillet in oil. Add the chicken to the skillet and cook on each side for 5-7 minutes, or until it is well browned on the outside and cooked through. Transfer the chicken to a clean cutting board, let it rest for five minutes, then dice it into small pieces. Place the chopped chicken in a bowl and refrigerate while you prepare the rest of the ingredients.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/cobb-salad-meal-prep/#wprm-recipe-37999-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add one inch of water in a pot, place a lid on top, then bring to a boil over high heat. Place four large eggs in a steaming basket, and once the water is boiling, carefully lower the basket into the pot. Replace the lid on top and allow the eggs to steam for 12 minutes. After 12 minutes, transfer the steaming basket and eggs to a bowl full of ice water to cool.", "name": "Add one inch of water in a pot, place a lid on top, then bring to a boil over high heat. Next, layer the chickpeas, tomatoes, and chopped chicken. Peel the eggs, slice or cut them into quarters, and add them to the dish. Crumble the bacon over top, followed by the cheese. Lastly, place a couple handfuls of fresh greens on top. Be sure not to pack it too tightly. Allowing air-flow will help keep the greens fresh.", "name": "To build the salads:&nbsp; Place 2 Tbsp dressing on the bottom of your container. Stir in an additional 1/2 cup flour. Turn the dough out onto a floured surface and knead for 5 minutes, slowly adding up to 1/2 cup more flour as you go. Be sure to add the flour slowly as you knead to prevent it from becoming too dry and stiff.", "name": "Pour the yeast water into the bowl of flour, then stir with a wooden spoon until fairly smooth. Divide it into two equal portions and form each piece into a ball. The perfect quick and satisfying weeknight dinner!\u00a0", "datePublished": "2020-05-17T09:32:06+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/One-Pot-Creamy-Sun-Dried-Tomato-Pasta-twirl.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/One-Pot-Creamy-Sun-Dried-Tomato-Pasta-twirl-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/One-Pot-Creamy-Sun-Dried-Tomato-Pasta-twirl-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/One-Pot-Creamy-Sun-Dried-Tomato-Pasta-twirl-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "One Pot Creamy Sun Dried Tomato Pasta", "description": "This incredibly fast and easy Creamy Sun Dried Tomato Pasta cooks in 30 minutes and uses just one pot. The perfect quick and satisfying weeknight dinner! FULL RECIPE BELOW. \ud83d\udc47\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/one-pot-creamy-sun-dried-tomato-pasta/\nTotal Cost: $4.22 recipe / $1.06 serving\n\nINGREDIENTS\n\u00bd cup sun dried tomatoes ($1.66)\n2 Tbsp butter ($0.26)\n2 cloves garlic, minced ($0.16)\n8 oz. fettuccine ($0.67)\n1/2 tsp dried basil ($0.05)\nFreshly cracked pepper ($0.05)\n2 cups chicken broth* ($0.26)\n2 oz. cream cheese ($0.30)\n1 cups whole milk ($0.37)\n1/4 cup grated Parmesan ($0.44)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Chop the sun dried tomatoes into small bite-sized pieces.\n2. Add the butter and garlic to a deep skillet or Dutch oven. Saut\u00e9 the garlic over medium heat for about one minute, or until it is very fragrant.\n3. Add the fettuccine, sun dried tomatoes, dried basil, some freshly cracked pepper, and the chicken broth to the skillet. If needed, break the fettuccine in half to make sure it lays flat in the skillet and is submerged in broth.\n4. Place a lid on the skillet, turn the heat up to high, and bring the broth to a boil. As soon as it reaches a boil, give the pasta a good stir, replace the lid, and turn the heat down to low or the lowest setting that maintains a simmer.\n5. Let the pasta simmer in the broth for 7-10 minutes, or until most of the broth is absorbed and the pasta is tender, stirring every couple of minutes and always replacing the lid.\n6. Keeping the heat on low, cut the cream cheese into chunks and stir it into the pasta. Once the cream cheese has melted, add the milk and stir until a smooth sauce forms. Finally, add the grated Parmesan over top and stir until it has melted into the sauce. Serve with extra freshly cracked pepper, if desired.\n\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTimestamp:\n0:00 Intro\n0:13 Add butter and garlic to a pan and saute until fragrant\n0:17 Add sun dried tomatoes, basil and cracked pepper\n0:21 Add fettuccine and chicken broth\n0:27 Cover and simmer for 7-10 minutes\n0:31 Stir often\n0:38 Add cream cheese and milk\n0:54 Add parmesan", "uploadDate": "2020-08-16T15:01:32+00:00", "duration": "PT1M15S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/pzeSSw-DQa8/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/pzeSSw-DQa8?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pzeSSw-DQa8", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeIngredient": ["\u00bd cup sun dried tomatoes ($1.66)", "2 Tbsp butter ($0.26)", "2 cloves garlic, minced ($0.16)", "8 oz. fettuccine ($0.67)", "1/2 tsp dried basil ($0.05)", "Freshly cracked pepper ($0.05)", "2 cups chicken broth* ($0.26)", "2 oz. cream cheese ($0.30)", "1 cups whole milk ($0.37)", "1/4 cup grated Parmesan ($0.44)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Chop the sun dried tomatoes into small bite-sized pieces.", "name": "Chop the sun dried tomatoes into small bite-sized pieces.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/one-pot-creamy-sun-dried-tomato-pasta/#wprm-recipe-31071-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the butter and garlic to a deep skillet or Dutch oven. I didn't quite double the recipe but I set it for 6 servings. Super cheesy and rich! I used about half of the milk that was recommended as I wanted more of a saucy texture that clung to the noodles, and I definitely prefer them this way. A cup and a half of milk felt excessive for 6 servings and would have completely drowned the noodles. It does lack a little depth, even when using extra garlic and extra sun dried tomatoes. I think next time I will use more sun dried tomatoes and possibly add a half of a cup of chopped up jarred roasted red peppers for some extra flavor. \r\n\r\nAlso for a bit of spice I added some red pepper flakes and it works really well to cut through some of that dense creamy cheesy sauce!\r\n\r\nVery easy recipe with lots of opportunities to experiment with- will try again with the addition of red peppers and more sun dried tomatoes. Brush all the potatoes with vegetable oil. Most of the time I use stevia, but Swerve tastes most like sugar and I definitely rely on it for some recipes. It's available in all of my local supermarkets as well as Walmart. I firmly believe that one problem with using \"artificial\" sweeteners is that most recipes and most prepared foods use too much. With modest use, it's usually hard to tell the difference between sugar and other sweeteners.\r\n\r\nAs a change of subject, you persuaded me to try a brine and my resulting grilled chicken was pretty good. I have been grilling for years, so my normal unbrined results are good, too, but it does take a watchful eye to keep boneless breasts from drying out and the brined chicken is more forgiving.  The rub, pretty normal, is nice, too, although I used more garlic and onion powders. Bringing the chicken to room temp prior to cooking is VERY important. Peel the ginger with a vegetable peeler or by scraping the skin with the sharp side of a spoon. Use a small holed cheese grater to grate the ginger. Add the garlic, ginger, the juice from half the lime (1.5-2 Tbsp), chili garlic sauce, soy sauce, honey, sesame oil, and vegetable oil to a medium bowl. Whisk together. Add the peanut butter and hot water, then whisk again until fairly smooth. Roughly chop the cilantro. Save a handful of the cilantro to top the dish after baking, and stir the rest into the peanut sauce.", "name": "Mince the garlic. Peel the ginger with a vegetable peeler or by scraping the skin with the sharp side of a spoon. Use a small holed cheese grater to grate the ginger. Add the peanut butter and hot water, then whisk again until fairly smooth. Roughly chop the cilantro. Place the chicken pieces and all the marinade from the bag in a casserole dish so that the pieces are in a single layer. Bake the chicken in the preheated oven for 30 minutes, then use a brush to add the reserved peanut sauce to the top of the chicken. Cook for an additional 15 minutes, then use a meat thermometer to test the internal temperature. If it's not up to 160 degrees Fahrenheit, bake 10-15 minutes more and then test again. Making great food is my passion, my purpose, and my favorite thing to share with others.", "sameAs": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/about/", "https://www.facebook.com/budgetbytes1", "https://x.com/Budget_Bytes"], "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/author/beth/"}, {"@type": "Recipe", "name": "Greek Chicken Pasta Salad", "author": {"@id": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/#/schema/person/de533a4dad507aefcf8ea04e131701f9"}, "description": "Greek Chicken Pasta Salad is the perfectly refreshing and filling summer meal with its medley of vegetables and tangy lemon garlic dressing.", "datePublished": "2025-05-17T08:30:00+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Greek-Chicken-Pasta-Salad-Overhead.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Greek-Chicken-Pasta-Salad-Overhead-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Greek-Chicken-Pasta-Salad-Overhead-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Greek-Chicken-Pasta-Salad-Overhead-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Greek Chicken Pasta Salad", "description": "Greek Chicken Pasta Salad is the perfectly refreshing and filling summer meal with its medley of vegetables and tangy lemon garlic dressing. Get the full recipe here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/greek-chicken-pasta-salad/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 lemon \n1/4 cup olive oil\n3 cloves garlic, divided \n1/2 Tbsp dried oregano\n1/2 tsp salt\nFreshly cracked pepper\n\nSALAD\n2 boneless, skinless chicken thighs\n8 oz. pasta (any shape) \n1 bell pepper (any color) \n4 oz. grape tomatoes*\n1/2 cucumber (1.5 cups diced) \n1/4 bunch parsley \n2 oz. feta \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Use a zester, microplane, or small-holed cheese grater to remove the zest from the lemon. Set the zest aside. Squeeze the juice from the lemon into a separate bowl. You'll need at least 1/4 cup juice.\n2. Prepare the dressing and marinade by mincing two of the three cloves of garlic and combining them with 1/4 cup lemon juice, olive oil, oregano, salt, some freshly cracked pepper, and a pinch of the lemon zest. Whisk these ingredients until well combined.\n3. Place the chicken thighs in a small zip lock bag and add half of the dressing, saving the rest to add to the salad later. Mince one more clove of garlic and add it to the bag with the chicken and marinade. Squeeze the air out and massage the bag to make sure the thighs are well coated in the marinade. Refrigerate the thighs for at least 30 minutes.\n4. While the chicken is marinating, cook the pasta according to the package directions, drain in a colander, and let cool.\n5. Heat a skillet over a medium flame. Once hot, add the marinated chicken thighs and cook on each side until they are well browned and cooked through (about 5 minutes each side). \n6. There should be enough oil in the marinade to keep the meat from sticking. Remove the cooked chicken from the skillet and let it rest for about five minutes. Once slightly cooled, chop the chicken into smaller, bite-sized pieces.\n7. While the chicken is cooking, prepare the rest of the vegetables. Dice the cucumber and bell pepper. Slice the tomatoes in half (or dice if using Roma or regular tomatoes). Pull the parsley leaves from the stems and give them a rough chop.\n8. Finally, build the salad. Add the cooked and cooled pasta to a large bowl. Top the pasta with the cucumber, bell pepper, tomatoes, parsley, and chopped chicken. Crumble the feta over top and add a pinch or two of the lemon zest. Pour the remaining dressing over the salad and toss to coat. Serve immediately or refrigerate until ready to eat.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-08-11T18:47:42+00:00", "duration": "PT1M1S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/thIrnnmgJAI/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/thIrnnmgJAI?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=thIrnnmgJAI", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4", "4 to 6"], "prepTime": "PT40M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT60M", "recipeIngredient": ["1  lemon ($0.59)", "3 cloves garlic, divided ($0.12)", "1/4 cup olive oil ($0.88)", "1/2 Tbsp dried oregano ($0.15)", "1/2 tsp salt  ($0.02)", "Freshly cracked pepper ($0.03)", "2  boneless, skinless chicken thighs* ($2.61)", "8 oz. pasta (any shape) ($0.59)", "1/2  cucumber (1.5 cups diced) ($0.37)", "1  bell pepper (any color) ($1.48)", "1/4 cup pitted Kalamata olives ($1.08)", "4 oz. grape tomatoes** ($1.19)", "1/4  bunch parsley  ($0.20)", "2 oz. feta  ($1.36)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use a zester, microplane, or small-holed cheese grater to remove the zest from the lemon. FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n15 oz. can black beans\n15 oz. can black eyed peas \n1 bell pepper (any color)\n2 Roma tomatoes \n1 jalape\u00f1o \n1/4 red onion \n1/4 bunch fresh cilantro \nDRESSING\n2 Tbsp olive oil\n1 fresh lime (2 Tbsp juice) \n1/2 Tbsp balsamic vinegar \n1/2 tsp chili powder*\n1 tsp cumin \n1/2 tsp salt\n1/2 tsp sugar \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Rinse and drain both cans of beans in a colander. Let the excess water drain as you prepare the vegetables.\n2. Finely dice the bell pepper, tomatoes, jalape\u00f1o, and red onion. Try to dice the vegetables into pieces that are roughly the same size as the beans. For a less spicy salad, scrape the seeds out of the jalape\u00f1o before dicing. Roughly chop the cilantro. Place the drained beans, bell pepper, tomatoes, jalape\u00f1o, onion, and cilantro in a large bowl.\n3. In a small bowl, whisk together the olive oil, 2 Tbsp of juice from the lime, balsamic vinegar, chili powder, cumin, salt, and sugar. Pour the dressing over the salad, then stir until everything is well coated. Serve immediately, or refrigerate until ready to eat.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-07-07T17:13:27+00:00", "duration": "PT55S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Ioa_cpUNrVo/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/Ioa_cpUNrVo?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ioa_cpUNrVo", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["10", "10 (1/2 cup each)"], "prepTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT20M", "recipeIngredient": ["2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.22)", "1  fresh lime (2 Tbsp juice) ($0.25)", "1/2 Tbsp balsamic vinegar  ($0.10)", "1/2 tsp chili powder** ($0.05)", "1 tsp ground cumin  ($0.10)", "1/2 tsp salt  ($0.02)", "1/2 tsp sugar  ($0.02)", "1 15oz. can black beans ($0.94)", "1 15oz. can black eyed peas*** ($1.24)", "1  bell pepper (any color) ($1.48)", "2  Roma tomatoes  ($0.48)", "1  jalape\u00f1o  ($0.33)", "1/4  red onion  ($0.11)", "1/4 bunch fresh cilantro  ($0.20)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a small bowl, whisk together the olive oil, 2 Tbsp of juice from the lime, balsamic vinegar, chili powder, cumin, salt, and sugar.", "name": "In a small bowl, whisk together the olive oil, 2 Tbsp of juice from the lime, balsamic vinegar, chili powder, cumin, salt, and sugar.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/cowboy-caviar/#wprm-recipe-30633-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Rinse and drain both cans of beans in a colander. Using a sharp paring knife carefully cut and remove the stem from the top half of each bell pepper (see picture below). It&#39;s okay if there is a small hole left where the stem was removed.", "name": "Prep the peppers", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/stuffed-bell-peppers/#wprm-recipe-83173-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place each bell pepper half in a 9x13-inch casserole dish. Brush the bell peppers with 1 Tbsp oil and season with \u00bc tsp of salt and \u00bc tsp cracked black pepper. Bake the bell peppers in a preheated oven for 20 minutes to soften. After 20 minutes remove the bell peppers from the oven and set aside. ***", "name": "Prebake the peppers", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/stuffed-bell-peppers/#wprm-recipe-83173-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "While the bell peppers are baking, make the filling. Continue to saut\u00e9 over medium heat until the onion is translucent and the garlic is fragrant.", "name": "Saut\u00e9", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/stuffed-bell-peppers/#wprm-recipe-83173-step-0-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Next add the uncooked rice, marinara sauce, Italian seasoning, garlic powder, 1 tsp of salt, and chicken broth to the skillet. Once boiling, immediately reduce the heat to medium-low and allow the mixture to simmer, without lifting the lid or stirring, for 20 minutes. After 20 minutes, turn the heat off and let it rest, without lifting the lid, for an additional 5 minutes.", "name": "Simmer", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/stuffed-bell-peppers/#wprm-recipe-83173-step-0-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Next remove the lid, fluff the rice, and stir the mixture again to redistribute the ingredients. This recipe stays on repeat at our house!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Rene Kimray"}, "datePublished": "2025-07-11"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "I always cut my peppers in half--lengthwise--and mound the filling. I also precook the peppers slightly  in a covered dish in the microwave, unbrushed and unsalted, as we love peppers and prefer them soft enough to cut with a fork. The amount of filling in the recipe is about right if the peppers are cut this way, but if there's any extra, just put it in the pan and surround the peppers. We like onion, so the amount is ok for my family--about 1 c of diced onion. I also use fresh garlic--3 cloves is about 1 T if they are large, but if not I use another clove or two. Italian sausage tends to be pretty salty, although it can vary widely, so I didn't add any more. There is at least one complaint about this recipe being \"too salty,\" which makes me wonder why the cook--who already knows how much salt satisfies their individual taste--didn't start without it and taste the filling it see if more was needed before stuffing the peppers. And a bit more cheese as my cutting difference created more surface area. The leftovers freeze just fine as anyone who has purchased a well known brand of stuffed peppers from the freezer section of their supermarket can attest.\r\n\r\nWith minor changes which in no way affect the recipe as written--only some procedural differences--the recipe is absolutely delicious!! I did use ripe peppers--a package of 3 from Aldi is always a bargain--we love the sweet taste of ripe ones over the more bitter taste of green peppers.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "janmaus"}, "datePublished": "2025-05-14"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "This is a great recipe! I just made it tonight and my husband and I really enjoyed them =)", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Jeanette from Denver"}, "datePublished": "2025-04-28"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "2"}, "reviewBody": "You guys, this is a surprisingly bad recipe! Cutting the peppers in half leaves you with some very small \"cups\" to put your filling in, and half of the cups will have very large holes in the bottom. Yes, you mention that, but normal bell peppers have pretty large stems. Just cut the tops off and scoop out the innards to give you greater volume. Avoid waste by dicing pepper flesh around the stem and saving it for an omelette or frittata or something.\r\n\r\nThe volume of the filling ingredients (1lb sausage, an onion, a cup of sauce, the rice, et. al.) probably results in about 8 cups prepared. That doesn't fit in 3 bell peppers. Probably needs 2x that number. \r\n\r\nOne onion is overpowering, especially since you call for processed marinara sauce. And you've got a fair amount of fresh garlic and dried garlic.\r\n\r\nPrecooking the peppers is unnecessary. Cut the cooking time of the filling. Brushing and salting the peppers -- huh?\r\n\r\nI'm hardly Julia Child, and I'm sure you are all great cooks, but this one seems \"off.\" Lol I know the internet is a nasty place, I don't remember the last time I bothered to post something negative about a recipe, and I feel bad about adding negativity, but I can't help it. We've made it a slightly easier, quicker, and budget-friendly dinner that takes less than 30 minutes!\n\nChicken Parmesan is everything you want in a cozy meal\u2013 crispy, saucy chicken topped with melty cheese! This one-pan chicken parmesan recipe is so easy to make and guaranteed to be a hit. FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/spicy-chorizo-cheese-dip/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1/2 lb. Mexican chorizo\n1 10 oz. can diced tomatoes with green chiles (like Rotel) \n1 12 oz. can evaporated milk \n12 oz. Monterey jack cheese*, shredded \n3 green onions (garnish) \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Brown the chorizo in a skillet over medium heat until it is slightly crispy on the edges. If your chorizo is very fatty, drain some of it off before the next step (leave a couple of tablespoons of fat in the skillet).\n2. Drain the diced tomatoes with green chiles, then add it to the skillet with the chorizo, and continue to stir and cook until most of the moisture from the canned tomatoes has evaporated away.\n3. Pour the evaporated milk into the skillet. Stir and cook until heated through.\n4. Turn the heat under the skillet down to low. Begin adding the cheese, one handful at a time, stirring until it is fully melted in before adding the next handful. \n5. Once all the cheese has melted into the dip, turn the heat off. Garnish with sliced green onion and serve!\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2018-12-02T17:52:51+00:00", "duration": "PT57S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/IKGJy2VQjOA/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/IKGJy2VQjOA?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IKGJy2VQjOA", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["6", "6 1/2 cup each"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT20M", "recipeIngredient": ["1/2 lb. Mexican chorizo ($1.37)", "1 10oz. can diced tomatoes with green chiles (like Rotel) ($1.06)", "1 12oz. can evaporated milk ($1.42)", "12 oz. Monterey jack cheese*, shredded ($2.95)", "3  green onions (garnish) ($0.25)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Brown the chorizo in a skillet over medium heat until it is slightly crispy on the edges. If your chorizo is very fatty, drain some of it off before the next step (leave a couple of tablespoons of fat in the skillet).", "name": "Brown the chorizo in a skillet over medium heat until it is slightly crispy on the edges. Cook it quickly in a skillet or throw it on the grill for a fast dinner!&nbsp;", "datePublished": "2019-04-28T17:27:17+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Easy-Cilantro-Lime-Chicken-skillet-close.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Easy-Cilantro-Lime-Chicken-skillet-close-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Easy-Cilantro-Lime-Chicken-skillet-close-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Easy-Cilantro-Lime-Chicken-skillet-close-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Easy Cilantro Lime Chicken", "description": "Easy Cilantro Lime Chicken is full of the bright fresh flavors of summer. Cook it quickly in a skillet or throw it on the grill for a fast dinner! FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/easy-cilantro-lime-chicken/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n2 Tbsp olive oil \n4 cloves garlic, minced \n1/2 tsp cumin \n1/2 tsp salt \nfreshly cracked pepper \n2 limes, divided\n1/2 bunch cilantro, divided\n6 boneless, skinless chicken thighs (1.5 to 1.75 lbs. total) \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n\n1. Combine the olive oil, minced garlic, cumin, salt, and some freshly cracked pepper (about 10 cranks of a pepper mill) in a small bowl.\n2. Zest one of the limes and then squeeze the juice. You'll need 2-3 Tbsp juice, so if needed, juice half of the second lime. Cut the remaining lime into wedges to garnish the chicken once cooked. Roughly chop the cilantro.\n3. Add 1 tsp of the lime zest, 2-3 Tbsp of the lime juice, and half of the chopped cilantro to the marinade. Stir to combine. (The remaining cilantro will be added fresh after cooking the chicken.)\n4. Place the chicken thighs in a shallow dish or a large zip top bag. Add the marinade and toss the chicken to coat. Allow the chicken to marinate for 30 minutes or up to 8 hours (refrigerated), turning it once or twice as it marinates.\n5. When ready to cook the chicken, heat a large skillet over medium-high heat. Once hot, add the chicken and cook for 5-7 minutes on each side, or until well browned and cooked through. My chicken had enough of an oil coating from the marinade that I did not need to add any extra to the skillet.\n6. Top the cooked chicken with more fresh cilantro and a squeeze of fresh lime juice. Serve with any extra lime wedges.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2019-05-19T17:40:38+00:00", "duration": "PT1M1S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/t9jShxWb1gU/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/t9jShxWb1gU?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t9jShxWb1gU", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["6", "6 one thigh each"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT55M", "recipeIngredient": ["2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.32)", "4 cloves garlic, minced ($0.32)", "1/2 tsp cumin ($0.05)", "1/2 tsp salt ($0.02)", "freshly cracked pepper ($0.05)", "2  limes, divided ($0.40)", "1/2 bunch cilantro, divided ($0.40)", "6  boneless, skinless chicken thighs (1.5 to 1.75 lbs. total) ($5.11)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine the olive oil, minced garlic, cumin, salt, and some freshly cracked pepper (about 10 cranks of a pepper mill) in a small bowl.", "name": "Combine the olive oil, minced garlic, cumin, salt, and some freshly cracked pepper (about 10 cranks of a pepper mill) in a small bowl.", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/easy-cilantro-lime-chicken/#wprm-recipe-43773-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Zest one of the limes and then squeeze the juice. Unsurprisingly, the pasta water behaves differently if it's the floury water vs the chickpea water. It just didn't emulsify the  cheese with the rest of the liquid, so it was more of a...cheese suspension...than a sauce. But it still tasted good! FULL RECIPE BELOW \ud83d\udc47 \n\nGet recipe FAQs, substitutions, and a printable version here: https://www.budgetbytes.com/vegetarian-french-dip-sandwiches/\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 yellow onion ($0.32)\n3 portobello mushroom caps (about \u00bd lb.) ($3.99)\n2 Tbsp butter ($0.20)\n1/8 tsp salt ($0.01)\n1/8 tsp freshly cracked black pepper ($0.01)\n1/4 tsp dried thyme ($0.02)\n1/4 tsp dried oregano ($0.02)\n2 cups vegetable broth* ($0.26)\n1 Tbsp soy sauce ($0.06)\n1/2 Tbsp brown sugar ($0.02)\n1/8 tsp garlic powder ($0.01)\n4 6-inch French or Hoagie rolls ($1.66)\n4 slices provolone ($1.00)\n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Slice the onion into thin strips. Rinse the portobello caps to remove any dirt or debris. Slice each cap in half, then crosswise into 1/4-inch thick strips.\n2. Add the butter to a deep skillet along with the sliced onions. Saut\u00e9 the onions over medium heat for a few minutes, or just until they begin to soften.\n3. Add the sliced mushrooms to the skillet along with the salt, pepper, thyme, and oregano. Saut\u00e9 the mushrooms until they release all their moisture and the liquid in the bottom of the skillet has evaporated (about 10 minutes). You should see some browned bits coating the bottom of the skillet.\n4. Add the vegetable broth, soy sauce, brown sugar, and garlic powder and stir to dissolve the browned bits from the bottom of the skillet. Allow the liquid to come up to a simmer, then turn down to low and simmer for about 5 minutes while you toast the bread.\n5. Open the rolls and place them on a baking sheet, open sides up. Turn the oven on to broil and place the rolls in the oven on the middle rack. Watch the rolls closely and broil just until you see a slightly browning on the edges (about 5 minutes).\n6. Use a slotted spoon or tongs to take the mushrooms and onions out of the au jus. Divide the mushrooms and onions among the four rolls. Top each sandwich with a slice of provolone.\n7. Return the sandwiches to the oven and broil for a few minutes more, or just until the cheese is melted. Close the sandwiches up and serve with the au jus from the skillet for dipping.\n\nNOTES\n*The type of broth you use will greatly affect the end flavor of the au jus. I used vegetable flavored Better Than Bouillon concentrate to make my vegetable broth.\nSee how we calculate recipe costs here. https://www.budgetbytes.com/how-to-calculate-recipe-costs/\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes\n\nTIME STAMPS \n0:00 Introduction\n0:06 Saut\u00e9 onions in butter\n0:11 Add mushrooms and seasoning\n0:22 Add broth and remaining ingredients to skillet\n0:30 Simmer\n0:33 Broil rolls\n0:37 Fill rolls with mushrooms and onions\n0:41 Top mushrooms and onions with cheese & ENJOY!", "uploadDate": "2022-08-07T15:00:11+00:00", "duration": "PT59S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Tvr-lHoO7Fs/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/Tvr-lHoO7Fs?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tvr-lHoO7Fs", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT35M", "recipeIngredient": ["1  yellow onion ($0.32)", "3  portobello mushroom caps (about \u00bd lb.) If they look like the chocolate chips in the step photos below, this step is done! It's the shortcut pasta version of Jambalaya!", "datePublished": "2015-02-17T18:09:51+00:00", "image": ["https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Pastalaya-Bowl.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Pastalaya-Bowl-500x500.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Pastalaya-Bowl-500x375.jpg", "https://www.budgetbytes.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Pastalaya-Bowl-480x270.jpg"], "video": {"name": "Pastalaya", "description": "This one pot pasta is an easy crowd pleaser and a great dish for weekly meal prep! FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/2015/02/pastalaya/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n1 Tbsp vegetable oil \n1/2 lb smoked sausage (preferably Andouille) \n2 cloves garlic \n10 oz bag frozen \"seasoning mix\"*\n15 oz can diced tomatoes \n1/2 Tbsp Creole seasoning** \n1/2 tsp oregano\n1/2 tsp smoked paprika\n1/4 tsp thyme \nFreshly cracked pepper \n2 cups chicken broth \n1 cup water\n1 lb penne pasta \n2 Tbsp half and half or cream \n1/2 bunch fresh parsley \n1/2 bunch green onions \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Slice the smoked sausage into thin rounds, then cut any larger pieces in half. Add the sausage and vegetable oil to a large pot and cook over medium heat until the sausage is well browned (about 5 minutes).\n2. Mince two cloves of garlic and add them to the pot. Saut\u00e9 for one minute, or until the garlic is soft and fragrant. Add the bag of frozen seasoning mix and saut\u00e9 until heated through (3-5 minutes). Add the can of diced tomatoes (with juices), Creole seasoning, oregano, smoked paprika, thyme, freshly cracked pepper (about 20 cranks of a pepper mill), and pasta to the pot. Finally, add the chicken broth and 1 cup of water, and stir until everything is evenly combined.\n3. Place a lid on the pot and turn the heat up to medium-high. Let the pot come to a boil. As soon as it reaches a boil, stir briefly, replace the lid, turn the heat down to low, and let the pot simmer for 10-12 minutes, or until the pasta is tender. Stir the pot once every few minutes as it simmers to prevent the pasta from sticking. Replace the lid as quickly as possible to maintain a simmer. If the mixture still seems soupy at around 8 minutes, let the pot simmer without a lid for the last few minutes. A little bit of thick sauce at the bottom of the pot is perfect.\n4. While the pasta is simmering, chop the parsley and slice the green onions.\n5. Turn off the heat and stir in the half & half or cream. Stir in most of the chopped parsley and green onions, reserving some to sprinkle over top of each bowl. Serve hot.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2018-03-04T16:45:01+00:00", "duration": "PT1M4S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/DKkAihwLH_0/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/DKkAihwLH_0?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DKkAihwLH_0", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["6", "6 (1.5 cups each)"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT35M", "totalTime": "PT45M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 Tbsp vegetable oil ($0.04)", "1/2 lb. smoked sausage (preferably Andouille) ($2.50)", "2 cloves garlic ($0.16)", "1 10oz. bag frozen \"seasoning mix\"* ($1.29)", "1 15oz. can diced tomatoes ($0.59)", "1/2 Tbsp Creole seasoning** ($0.15)", "1/2 tsp oregano ($0.05)", "1/2 tsp smoked paprika ($0.05)", "1/4 tsp thyme ($0.02)", "Freshly cracked pepper ($0.03)", "2 cups chicken broth ($0.26)", "1 cup water ($0.00)", "1 lb. penne pasta ($1.39)", "2 Tbsp half and half or cream ($0.11)", "1/2 bunch fresh parsley ($0.45)", "1/2 bunch green onions ($0.42)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Slice the smoked sausage into thin rounds, then cut any larger pieces in half. However, I want to stress that this is New Orleans style pastalaya. I used to cook jambalaya and pastalaya that way, too, because I'm originally from Chalmette. However, I now live in the Gonzales area. Gonzales is known as the jambalaya capital of the world. They do t make a tomato based jambalaya or pastalaya...they make it roux jambalaya and pastalaya. So if you leave out the tomatoes and make a roux instead, add some pork temple meat or bite sized pieces of the darker meat of the Boston butt portion, use beef broth instead of chicken and use spaghetti noodles instead of penne, you will have what we in Gonzales call pastalaya. I like it both ways! Goes great with grilled meats or your favorite vegetarian platter. Take advantage of that fresh summer produce with this Super Fresh Cucumber Salad.  FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/2017/03/super-fresh-cucmber-salad/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\nRED WINE VINAIGRETTE\n1/4 cup olive oil \n2 Tbsp red wine vinegar \n1 Tbsp lemon juice \n1 tsp dried oregano \n1/2 tsp salt \nFreshly cracked pepper \nSALAD\n2 cucumbers \n4 Roma tomatoes (about 1 lb.) \n1/2 small red onion\n1 green bell pepper\n1/4 bunch parsley \n2 oz feta \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Prepare the vinaigrette first to let the flavors blend as you prepare the rest of the salad. In a small bowl whisk together the olive oil, red wine vinegar, lemon juice, oregano, salt, and some freshly cracked pepper. Set the dressing aside.\n2. Peel the cucumbers if desired. Dice the cucumbers, tomatoes, and bell pepper. Thinly slice the red onion*. Pull the parsley leaves from their stems, then give them a rough chop. Crumble the feta cheese.\n3. Place the cucumbers, tomatoes, bell pepper, red onion, parsley, and feta in a large bowl. Pour the dressing over top, and toss to combine. Serve immediately or refrigerate until ready to eat. This salad holds up well over a few days in the refrigerator. Be sure to stir briefly to redistribute the flavors before serving.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2017-07-17T20:22:41+00:00", "duration": "PT50S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/JduJWmH3U80/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/JduJWmH3U80?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JduJWmH3U80", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["6", "6 1-1.25 cups per serving"], "prepTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT20M", "recipeIngredient": ["1/4 cup olive oil  ($0.52)", "2 Tbsp red wine vinegar  ($0.20)", "1 Tbsp lemon juice  ($0.06)", "1 tsp dried oregano  ($0.10)", "1/2 tsp salt  ($0.02)", "Freshly cracked pepper ($0.03)", "2  cucumbers  ($1.58)", "4  Roma tomatoes (about 1 lb.) Remove the core from the cabbage and cut into thin strips. Slice the onion into thin strips. Cut the broccoli into bite-sized pieces. When the oil is hot, add the grated ginger, saute for about 30 seconds to one minute (its okay if it sticks to the pan but don\u2019t let it burn). Use only 1/2 tsp of sriracha if you don\u2019t want it spicy, use up to 1 Tbsp if you like it hot. Stir until the ketchup and sugar are dissolved. Pour the sauce into the skillet with the chicken and vegetables with the heat still on medium high. Add the noodles, stir to coat everything in the sauce, and heat through (just a few minutes).", "name": "In a small bowl, combine the soy sauce, worcestershire sauce, ketchup, sriracha, and sugar. This will become your new favorite quick weeknight meal. FULL RECIPE BELOW.\n\nPRINTABLE RECIPE: https://www.budgetbytes.com/curried-chickpeas-spinach/\n\nFull Recipe \ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\ud83d\udc47\n\nINGREDIENTS\n2 Tbsp olive oil \n1 small onion \n2 cloves garlic \n1 inch fresh ginger \n1 1/2 Tbsp curry powder\n8 oz spinach fresh or frozen \n15 oz can tomato sauce \n29 oz can chickpeas \n\nINSTRUCTIONS\n1. Dice the onion, mince the garlic, and grate the ginger on a small holed cheese grater. Saut\u00e9 the onion, garlic, and ginger in a large skillet with the olive oil over medium heat until the onions have softened (3-5 minutes).\n2. Add the curry powder and continue to saut\u00e9 with the onion mixture for one minute more. Add about 1/4 cup of water to the skillet along with the fresh spinach and continue to saut\u00e9 until the spinach has wilted. The water will help steam and wilt the spinach (no water needed if using frozen spinach).\n3. Drain and rinse the chickpeas. Add them to the skillet along with the tomato sauce. Stir well to distribute the spices in the sauce and heat through (5 minutes). Serve over rice or with bread.\n\n\nInstagram: budgetbytes\nFacebook: budgetbytes1\nPinterest: budgetbytes\nTwitter: budget_bytes", "uploadDate": "2018-06-17T22:11:38+00:00", "duration": "PT56S", "thumbnailUrl": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/1EiIzHJJFTk/hqdefault.jpg", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/1EiIzHJJFTk?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1EiIzHJJFTk", "@type": "VideoObject"}, "recipeYield": ["4", "4 1 cup each"], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT25M", "recipeIngredient": ["2 Tbsp olive oil ($0.44)", "1  yellow onion ($0.70)", "2 cloves garlic ($0.08)", "1 inch fresh ginger ($0.16)", "1 1/2 Tbsp curry powder ($0.45)", "8 oz. spinach (fresh or frozen, $1.04)", "1 15 oz. can tomato sauce ($1.06)", "2 15 oz. cans chickpeas ($1.88)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Dice the onion, mince the garlic, and grate the ginger on a small holed cheese grater. Continue to boil the potatoes until they can easily be pierced with a fork (12-15 minutes).", "name": "Boil the potatoes", "url": "https://www.budgetbytes.com/german-potato-salad/#wprm-recipe-30753-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Meanwhile, add the bacon to a large skillet and cook over medium heat until the bacon is brown and crispy. Thanks!\u2764\ufe0f", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Judy"}, "datePublished": "2025-07-22"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "I've not been invited to answer this, but I poach chicken breasts all the time--it's takes a while on the stovetop, and slow and low is still the secret. I use a low simmer and it takes at least an hour for them to be really tender. That makes the slow cooker ideal, but mine, rarely used for years, is currently in my DDIL's pantry after loaning it a few years ago--so stovetop is my method. I add vegetables to the pot--a good sized yellow onion, with the skin attached to add color, a big stick of celery with a few of the leaves, a large carrot, a bay leaf or two and water to cover in a 4 qt  or larger pot. I start everything in cold water to cover and bring slowly up to a simmer as shocking the chicken in boiling water will toughen it. I add a few teaspoons of chicken bouillon late in the process as salting the chicken early can make it tough, too. The bouillon is basically flavored salt, and of course I use Better Than Bouillon brand. I freeze some of the shredded chicken, but it's so useful, it pretty much gets used up within a month without much effort. I don't  think I would freeze it long term.\r\n\r\nSo you can see that Jess's version is much less work and still delicious. I think you can follow her streamlined recipe exactly and cook on top of the stove, too. For safety reasons, I never leave a pot cooking unless I'm in the house, so it does take a time commitment. I strain the broth and use it for Texas style tortilla soup--Hub's favorite treat--which is a bit different from Beth's delicious version. But a simple chicken noodle soup with the very flavorful broth is also wonderful. \r\n\r\nAldi often has family packs of boneless chicken breast for $2.29 a lb--almost the cheapest protein available, as anything that costs less has bones. Their regular price is only $2.49 per lb, which is the \"on special\" price for my local premium supermarket.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "janmaus"}, "datePublished": "2025-07-21"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "This deserves 5 stars for the great meal prep. ideas here...I'm going to use them.
